Sources

 

 

The process of learning and understanding art is seen through the lens of art education, art scholarship and art criticism, and access to art collections and archive. The circulation of knowledge between these domains contributes to the discourse of art in every period in art history. The process of learning art through institutions in society, such as the community, schools and universities, church, state, and museums, contributes to how art is defined and valued at different contexts.

 

Art Education and Academe

Broadly conceived, art education is the learning and teaching of knowledge and skills in the visual arts not only to art students at the tertiary level but also to publics of diverse ages and talents. It includes instruction in the fine arts such as drawing, painting, and sculpture as well as media arts and crafts like advertising, furniture, and pottery. It may be conducted formally in school at different grade levels, or informally through workshops and apprenticeship.

The latter is the case among many Philippine ethnolinguistic groups. Traditions in art forms such as weaving, pottery, basketry, carving, jewelry making, and metalwork are passed on within a family or community. A young girl from the Cordilleras, for instance, learns how to spin, dye, and weave from her own mother or grandmother. In doing so, some places have become associated with particular products: Ilocos is known for its burnay and abel (blanket); Paete, Laguna, for wood carving; and Basey, Samar, for its colorful mats.

Conversely, artistic customs may disappear due to dearth and death of practitioners within a community. To address this, the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or National Living Treasure Award program was legislated in 1992 to give state recognition and support to traditional folk artists who exhibit technical and artistic excellence. Awardees are tasked to pass on their artistic traditions to their peoples in order to promote and preserve cultural heritage through the establishment of the School of Living Traditions in their communities.

The apprenticeship system likewise characterized art education during the 16th-18th centuries. Spanish missionary-artists opened workshops in their conventos (parish houses) in Intramuros and were sent to mission territories to instruct indios (Christianized native) and the Chinese on how to paint and sculpt religious images in the Western manner. Prints, especially from Flanders and Northern Europe, served as models for painting and sculpture and facilitated acquaintance with the European iconographic tradition. These religious images were made to adorn churches and to illustrate the teachings of Christianity, the major patron of the arts. By the same token, the typographic press—introduced by the friars by the early 17th century—produced devotional books, catechisms, dictionaries, estampas (large holy pictures), estampitas (small holy pictures), grammars, maps, and sermon collections. Like in painting and sculpture, knowledge in engraving and printing was transmitted to an apprentice or disciple who worked closely with a master to learn about the medium.

A more formal training in the visual arts emerged in the 19th century when the Academia de Dibujo, the first Manila art academy, was established in 1823 by the Real Sociedad Economica de Amigos del Pais. Its teacher and director Damian Domingo opened it to everybody, whether Spaniard, mestizo, or indio. Hitherto, many Filipino painters were either self-taught or learned informally from clerics. Domingo and the Real Sociedad also published Elementos de Perspectiva (Elements of Perspective) in 1828, positively indicating its academic orientation.

The first art academy, however, closed in 1834 due to lack of funds. Revived in 1850, its successor was patterned after the Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid where its directors had studied. Among the courses offered were modeling, figure drawing, drawing from life, and drawing from masterpieces. This learning-by-imitation model called for a museum to enable students to copy sculptures and paintings.

Initially a school for drawing and painting, the academia later added courses in engraving, lithography (1889), and sculpture (1893). Regardless of the course, learning was measured by a progressive mastery of simple to complex tasks. Drawing, believed to be the foundation of painting, was taught first. In anatomy classes, a student proceeded from drawing casts to painting live models. Incentives included awards, exhibits, as well as art scholarships to the Spanish peninsula. Among the notable products of the academy were Lorenzo Rocha, who later assumed co-directorship of the school after completing its first art scholarship to Spain, as well as Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo and Juan Luna.

The academia dissolved in 1898 with the change in colonial government from Spain to the United States. No formal art academy operated until the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts (UP SFA) opened in 1909. During the interval, artists like Teodoro Buenaventura, Fabian de la Rosa, and Rafael Enriquez offered private lessons in their studios.

 

 

Partly due to the efforts of the Asociacion International de Artistas organized by Enriquez, an escuella de bellas artes (school of fine arts) was reestablished and was attached as a charter unit of the University of the Philippines (UP). Enriquez served as the SFA’s first director. Majority of its founding faculty, like Buenaventura, Joaquin Herrera, Miguel Zaragoza, and de la Rosa, were instructors and/or graduates of the Academia de Dibujo. The UP SFA reproduced the European academic orientation of the latter, including the atelier and concours system. Instructions, such as life drawing classes, were given to groups of 20-35 students under a particular instructor. At the end of each semester, an exhibition was held and prizes were awarded. Five-year certificate courses in painting, sculpture, and engraving were offered; students were admitted via competitive examination.

Among the eminent early graduates were Fernando Amorsolo and Guillermo Tolentino, both of whom were soon invited as faculty and later assumed directorship of the school. Their lofty stature and influential romantic realist style closely identified the UP SFA with academism until the late 1950s.

In contrast, the fine arts and architecture program of the University of Santo Tomas (UST) was associated with modernism. It opened in 1930 with Victorio Edades as director. Notable modernists, including Carlos Francisco, Diosdado Lorenzo, Vicente Manansala, and Galo Ocampo, were invited by Edades to teach at UST. In 1938, Edades, Lorenzo, and Ocampo also established the Atelier of Modern Art in Manila. The distinction between the so-called conservative and modern art, which was applied by the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) in its painting categories from 1949 to 1955, was likewise implemented in the Shell National Students Art Competitions from 1953 to 1961. Most UP students won the prizes in conservative art while UST students garnered majority of awards in the modern category.

By the second half of the 20th century, other fine arts programs and organizations began to be established. In 1950, the Fine Arts Department of the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) was organized by Araceli Limcaco-Dans who later also co-founded with Brenda Fajardo the Philippine Art Education Association in 1968. The University of the East School of Music and Arts was established in 1964 with Pablo Victoria and Florencio Concepcion among its early directors. Far Eastern University opened its Institute of Architecture and Fine Arts in 1970 with Galo Ocampo as head of the Department of Fine Arts. Outside Manila, Martino Abellana was the prominent faculty in UP Cebu.

The fine arts curriculum also expanded in terms of course offerings and degree programs. A bachelor of fine arts major in advertising began to be offered by most of the aforementioned schools as well as by the College of Holy Spirit, the Far Eastern Air Transport Incorporated, and the Eulogio “Amang” Rodriguez Institute of Science and Technology, among others. Moreover, courses, if not degrees, in animation, art management, photography, video production, interior and industrial design have since been introduced.

Although often discussed in terms of instruction in skill courses, art education further includes the teaching of history, appreciation, and criticism of art. As early as 1912, the UP SFA administered a course in theory and history of art for its fourth year students. Vicente Alvarez Dizon taught drawing and art appreciation at the National Teachers College and lectured on history of art at the UP SFA from 1929 to 1941 and 1940 to 1947, respectively. From 1953 to 1960, Fernando Zobel lectured at Ateneo de Manila University (AdMU) in courses such as Introduction to Contemporary Painting, where he taught students how to look at painting as an artist might. In 1955, the UP College of Liberal Arts offered a course titled Humanities I, which included formal analysis of Western music and visual arts. By school year 1960-61, it became a required course for every UP student when it was incorporated into the general education program of the state university. Like Zobel, Humanities I treated art as a human(izing) experience rather than technical acquisition. Leopoldo Yabes, a proponent of the humanities program in UP, clarified that the humanities are intellectual disciplines, not vocational studies. Arts appreciation has since become a core course in the general education curriculum at the tertiary level.

Art education was likewise integrated in the curriculum of many primary and secondary schools. An early exponent was Dizon, author of Art Education and Appreciation, 1934, who advocated its inclusion to awaken an aesthetic sense in the early life of the youth. In 1941, the Bureau of Public Schools issued a Course of Study in Art Education for Elementary Schools. This was reportedly the first mention of “art education” as a subject. Hitherto, during the early American colonial period, “drawing” was the focus and nomenclature used in the study of art, which started as early as 1915 with the publication of Freehand Drawing for Primary Grades by the Department of Instruction. In 1963, Dans, who earlier developed the PWU Department of Fine Arts, also reorganized the art program of the Ateneo Grade School. Pablo Victoria wrote Art in the Elementary School, 1959, and Art Activities in the Elementary School, 1966. The Philippine High School for the Arts was established in 1977. Among the directors of this government-run school for artistically gifted students was another artist cum art educator Virginia Flor-Agbayani.

Workshops and internship programs facilitated by individual artists, art groups, institutions, and galleries are also venues for education in the arts. Manuel Rodriguez Sr conducted printmaking workshops during the 1960s, which was continued by Virgilio “Pandy” Aviado and younger members of the Printmakers Association of the Philippines. Nelfa Querubin in Iloilo, Tessy and Jon Pettyjohn in Laguna, the de Guzman family and Ugu Bigyan in Laguna teach pottery in their respective studios. Institutions like the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and the Lopez Museum provide on-the-job training to student volunteers in the various aspects of museum work.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, with notes from Roberto G. Paulino

 

Art Criticism

Aside from art education, another aspect in the production of knowledge in art is criticism. As distinguished from art history, art criticism is the evaluation of the artistic merits, historical significance, and cultural impact of artworks. It normally entails an ability to discern quality and skill in works, as defined by particular standards or canons of taste common to a time or place.

As a modern professional public practice, art criticism came to be increasingly allied in the 19th and 20th centuries with commodity market forces and their connection to the monitoring of changing trends in taste and fashion.

The speeches of Jose Rizal and Graciano Lopez Jaena at the banquet in honor of Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo provide one of the earliest examples of art criticism. According to Rizal, the gold and silver medals of Luna’s Spoliarium and Hidalgo’s Las Virgenes Cristianas Expuestas al Populacho (Christian Virgins Exposed to the Populace) at the 1884 Madrid Exposition demonstrated that genius can be found in all countries, thereby supporting the campaign for political equality.

During the American period, debate between conservative art and modern art stimulated critical writing about the nature of art. Artists and writers active in the debates included Edades, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Ariston Estrada, Salvador Lopez, Federico Mangahas, Ignacio Manlapaz, Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil, Tolentino, A.B. Saulo, and Jose Garcia Villa. The debate continued after World War II after the results of the inaugural 1948 AAP painting competitions led to the published exchanges between Edades and Tolentino.

By the 1950s, a new group of critics emerged and further broadened the support for modernism. This group included Aurelio S. Alvero, Francisco Arcellana, Leonidas Benesa, Ricaredo Demetillo, and Emmanuel Torres. Alvero, who used the pseudonym Magtanggol Asa, wrote the monograph of the First Exhibition of Non-Objective Art in Tagala presented by the Philippine Art Gallery (PAG) in 1953. Benesa and Torres, who were products of Ateneo and the Zobel lectures, as well as Arcellana and Demetillo, who were faculty members at the UP Department of English, were all winners in the AAP art criticism contest. Launched in 1954, the contest also lists critics Jolico Cuadra, Alice Guillermo, Cid Reyes, Reuben Cañete, and Ronald Achacoso as awardees.

The growing trend in the 1960s toward abstraction gave rise to questions of national identity vis-à-vis internationalism. In 1972, some of these art reviews first published in periodicals were compiled by Alice Coseteng in Philippine Modern Art and Its Critics. Aside from Benesa and Torres, other critics and book authors active in the 1970s were Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Alfredo Roces, and Paul Zafaralla. In the 1980s, Benesa, Angel de Jesus, and Guillermo also maintained regular art columns.

The relationship between the artist and critic is a perennial issue. A panel discussion on “The Role of the Critic” was organized by the Metropolitan Museum in 1990. An art criticism workshop facilitated by the UP Department of Art Studies was sponsored by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 1998. Competition and workshops continue with institutional support. Since 2009, UST conducts the J. Elizalde Navarro National Workshop in the Criticism on the Arts and Humanities. In 2014, the Metrobank Foundation added an art criticism competition to its visual arts program in painting, sculpture, interior design, and architecture, called Alice Guillermo Art Criticism Award. Also in 2014, an award called the Ateneo Art Awards–Purita Kalaw-Ledesma Prize for Art Criticism was instituted by the Ateneo Art Gallery and the Kalaw Ledesma Foundation Inc.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

Art Scholarship

Art scholarship is the systematic study of artworks, artists, and visual art forms. It consists of related disciplines such as art history, which traces the development of art within a social, cultural, and historical context; art theory and aesthetics, which discuss the theoretical underpinnings of art; and connoisseurship, which includes authenticating particular works. Art scholarship also involves art education and art criticism.

Art scholarship in the Philippines properly belongs in the postwar period. This period also saw the rise of galleries and the necessary documentation of works exhibited. The war years saw the printing of two catalogues on individual art collections: Paintings by Filipino Artists, 1943, on the art collection of Jorge B. Vargas; and Art in Tagala, 1941, on the Aurelio Alvero collection.

The year 1958 saw the beginning of art scholarship with the publication of Art of the Philippines 1521-1957, edited by Winfield Scott Smith III. This was the only extended study of Philippine art until the publication of Art in the Philippines, 1964, by Dominador Castañeda, a painter and teacher at the UP College of Fine Arts.

Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla, founder of the Philippine Art Gallery, also published some of the first writings on art later compiled for the seventh anniversary brochure of the PAG.

Seminal essays on Philippine culture were published in the 1960s in the journal Philippine Studies. Among these was Zobel de Ayala’s essay on the santo, which was later expanded to Philippine Religious Imagery, 1963, a survey of Spanish colonial religious culture based on extensive private collections.

Benesa wrote a shorter historical survey for the National Museum, which also published a series, Aspects of Philippine Culture, 1967-68, which included monographs on indigenous arts, music, architecture, and modern painting. These were written by leading experts of the time, among them William Beyer, Galo B. Ocampo, and Antonio Molina.

For its fourth issue in 1966, the Humanities journal of the University of the Philippines included articles by Josefa Lava, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Virginia Moreno, Napoleon Abueva, Abdulmari Imao, and Ricaredo Demetillo on the visual arts.

The next important survey of the arts appeared as part of The Filipino People, a 10-volume series compiling writings by different authors and published by Grolier Encyclopedia in 1981. The volume on Philippine art, edited by Felipe de Leon Jr, presented the arts in the context of history and took advantage of scholarly developments up to 1971. Improved color printing technology later gave rise to art publications—meaning, books that combined technically competent photographs with substantial text. In the 1970s, art publishing became a phenomenon, starting with Manuel D. Duldulao’s Contemporary Philippine Art, 1972, containing informative material and good color reproductions that stimulated the art market. A survey from the 1970s was Julian Dacanay’s Trends Report, published as a mimeographed text and then later as part of Ethnic Houses and Other Essays, 1990.

In the 1970s, books on art that combined criticism with history were published by the Bureau of National and Foreign Information. These include Torres’s Ang Kiukok Drawings, 1975, and Aguilar Cruz’s Luna, 1975.

Combining art history and connoisseurship, Santiago Pilar wrote an exhaustive work, Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter, 1980, published by the Eugenio Lopez Foundation. A specialist on old masters, Santiago Pilar also did a book on the Vargas collection at UP and on Domingo Celis. In 1998, Jun Terra published a book titled Juan Luna Drawings: The Paris Period, documenting the collection of Dr Eleuterio M. Pascual. In 1998, Alfredo Roces published the first book on Hidalgo, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo and the Generation of 1872. Both Luna and Hidalgo were the subjects of a show and an accompanying bilingual catalogue, Oro Plata (Gold Silver), at the Metropolitan Museum in 1989.

While Jaime Laya was governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), the bank published, beginning 1981, its Kayamanan (Wealth) series of books: on its painting collection written by Torres, on antique gold jewelry by Ramon Villegas, and on ceramics by noted collectors. The BSP had gathered an impressive collection of 19th-century paintings of various forms and styles, from the miniaturist painting of the first half of the 19th century to the academic paintings of Luna and Hidalgo. A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces, 1986, was intended to be a teaching tool, which contains a handbook of essays on specific works by various scholars and 60 full-color reproductions printed on separate heavy-stock paper. In 2001, Laya himself authored the book Letras y Figuras (Letters and Figures).

 

These art books were supplemented by art publications that appeared in the 1970s and 1980s. One of these was Archipelago, a monthly magazine that appeared from 1974 to 1981 and which featured articles on old and contemporary masters, accompanied by color reproductions of their works. This magazine served as training ground in art criticism for young practitioners. A short-lived venture was the magazine Gallery Hopper. More recent publications featuring the arts are the Philippine Quarterly of Culture and Society; Philippine Studies of AdMU; and Arts Monthly and, later, Kultura magazine of the CCP.

A contribution to scholarship was the 10-volume Filipino Heritage, 1978, which contained short articles on art forms among the many articles that touched on all aspects of the Philippines. Lavishly illustrated, it was a treasure trove of visual data on the arts. This was followed later by the survey People and Art of the Philippines, 1981, by Gabriel Casal and others, published in connection with an exhibit held at the Museum of Cultural History of the University of California in Los Angeles. Another survey, Philippinische Malerei (Philippine Painting), was published in 1970 in connection with an exhibit in Germany.

Private individuals and foundations funded books, such as Paras-Perez’s Tolentino, 1976; Manansala Nudes, 1989; Sanso: Art Quest between Two Worlds, 1988; and Zobel, 1990. Paras-Perez also published a number of brochures on the early modernists for the Galerie Bleue. In The Filipino Nude, 1977, Alfredo Roces did a survey of the nude from the Spanish period to the present. He also did Amorsolo, 1975, and Sanso, 1976, as well as Philippine Cartoons 1900-1941, 1985, the latter co-authored with historian Alfred McCoy. Angel de Jesus, a member of the prewar Veronicans, continued to write on art in his columns and came out with a book, Hernando R. Ocampo: The Artist as Filipino, 1979. Earlier, Beatrice Harding’s Survival through Art, 1974, documented the development of the art of printmaker Manuel Rodriguez Sr.

Kalaw-Ledesma and Amadis Ma. Guerrero collaborated on the books Struggle for Philippine Art, 1974, and Edades, National Artist, 1979. Kalaw-Ledesma later drew from her large collection of primary sources to produce an originally designed book on the PAG. Benesa’s Okir, 1982, focused on printmaking, which has its roots in indigenous wood carving. A book on religious prints, The Filipino Engraving, 1980, was put together by a number of specialists, including the historian Jesus Merino, Paras-Perez, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya. The book had the added value of reproducing prints from copperplates hitherto unknown and stored in the UST Museum. Paras-Perez also wrote the book Manansala, 1980.

In the 1980s, public interest in art was maintained through regular columns written by Benesa, de Jesus, and Guillermo, among others. Guillermo also came out with Mobil Art Awards, 1980; Social Realism in the Philippines, 1987; Blanco, 1987; Alfredo Carmelo: His Life and Art, 1990; Cebu: A Heritage of Art, 1991; and the National Museum Visual Arts Collections, 1992. From Anito to Assemblage, 1991, by Guillermo and others, was published in conjunction with a retrospective of sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. Reyes wrote a book on Ben Cabrera in Etchings 1970-1980, 1986, and later compiled his interviews of various painters and sculptors into Conversations on Philippine Art, 1989. Art critic and scholar Paul Zafaralla came out with a book on the art educator Pablo Victoria, 1986; collaborated with Virginia Ty-Navarro on a work Carlos V. Francisco: The Man and Genius of Philippine Art, 1985; and also co-authored a book on Legaspi’s drawings. Books on significant Filipino artists were published in the 1990s, such as Kiukok: The Artist and His Work, 1991, by Esperanza Gatbonton; Legaspi: The Making of a National Artist, 1993, by Alfredo Roces; Exploding Galaxies: The Art of David Medalla, 1995, by Guy Brett; and A Sense of Serenity: Anita Magsaysay-Ho with Twelve Young Poets, 1996, by Charlson Ong.

In early 1993 the Crucible Workshop published Art Philippines edited by Juan T. Gatbonton, Jeannie E. Javelosa, and Lourdes Ruth R. Roa. It covers painting and sculpture from the Spanish colonial to the contemporary period. The writers are Benesa, Zafaralla, Torres, Guillermo, Reyes, Luciano Santiago, and Cesare Syjuco.

The CCP, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and the National Museum have been crucial in exhibitions of the visual arts. These are often accompanied by substantial catalogues. One of the CCP’s important projects has been the Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art) series of 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson. The first seven monographs were later put together into an illustrated coffee-table book by the editor. Later, Tiongson also edited the 10-volume CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994, which dedicated one whole volume to the visual arts, edited by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Alice Guillermo, and Santiago Pilar. CCP also published Igkas-Arte: The Philippine Arts during the Spanish Period, 1998.

In 1998, Discovering Philippine Art in Spain was published to commemorate the centennial celebration of the proclamation of Philippine independence, presenting artworks from the collection of various Spanish cultural institutions. The book includes discussion in ethnological art, Muslim military art, Christian art, and secular art, written by Jose Maria Cariño, Felice Sta. Maria, Brenda Fajardo, Abraham Sakili, Regalado Trota Jose, and Santiago Pilar.

 

The commemoration of the anniversary of an art award-giving body yielded publications that reviewed the winners of art competitions, such as Ginto: 50 Years of the Art Association of the Philippines: 1948-1997, 1999, edited by Reuben Ramas Cañete, and Metrobank Foundations MADE of Gold, 2013, celebrating the 50th anniversary of the bank and the 30th year of the competition. Publications on art history offering new research and perspectives continued in the 1990s to the 2000s, spurred by the postcolonial studies and concepts of new art history, which is interested in the social forces that affect the production of art and the considerations of issues of social class, gender, race, and ethnicity in art historiography. These include Guillermo’s Image to Meaning: Essays in Philippine Art, 2001, which is a collection of essays on contemporary artists and the layered reading of their artworks, and Protest: Revolutionary Art in the Philippines, 1970-1990, 2001, which is considered an important contribution in establishing the history of the art of the protest movement in the Philippines; Patrick Flores’s Painting History: Revisions in Philippine Colonial Art, 1998, which offers the postcolonial perspective of resistance by the colonized in reading colonial art; Thelma B. Kintanar’s Self-Portraits: Twelve Filipina Artists Speak, 2000; Flaudette May Datuin’s Home Body Memory: Filipina Artists in the Visual Arts, 19th Century to the Present, 2002; and Eloisa May P. Hernandez’s Homebound: Women Visual Artists in Nineteenth Century Philippines, 2004, which explores the unwritten history of women artists in the Philippines; Ang Inukit na Kaalamang Bayan ng Paete (The Carved Folk Knowledge in Paete), 2005, by Brenda Fajardo, employing the interdisciplinary approach in studying folk art; and Abraham Sakili’s Space and Identity: Expressions in the Culture, Art and Society of the Muslims in the Philippines, 2003, which explores the role of Islamic beliefs and Southeast Asian links in the traditional art of the Muslim Filipino. New studies on the visual arts pertaining to the Japanese colonial period were published, such as Panahon ng Hapon: Sining sa Digmaan (Japanese Period: Art in War), 1992, by Marcelino Foronda, and Helen-Yu Rivera’s books on editorial cartoons during this period—namely, Patterns of Continuity and Change: Imaging the Japanese in Philippine Editorial Cartoons, 1930-1941 and 1946-1956, 2008, and A Satire of Two Nations: Exploring Images of the Japanese in Philippine Political Cartoons, 2010.

Books on significant Filipino artists were published in the 2000s, oftentimes coinciding with retrospective exhibitions of their works, exemplified by the release of Edades: From Freedom to Fruition, 2012, in connection with a retrospective exhibition on National Artist Victorio Edades at the CCP. Monographs published on the life and art of Filipino artists include Parallel Texts: Federico Aguilar Alcuaz with Rod Paras-Perez, 2005, by Rod Paras-Perez; Fabian de la Rosa and His Times, 2007, by Luciano Santiago; Inscapes: The Art of Agnes Arellano, 2008, by Alice Guillermo; The Life and Times of Damian Domingo, 2010, by Luciano Santiago; Immaterial: The Art of Augusto Albor and Abueva, both published in 2010, by Cid Reyes; The Life and Art of Botong Francisco and The Life and Art of Francisco Coching, both published in 2010, edited by Patrick D. Flores; Alter/(N)ations): The Art of Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, 2010, edited by Flaudette May Datuin; Carlos Villa and the Integrity of Spaces, 2011, by Theodore Gonzalves; The Life and Art of Lee Aguinaldo, 2011, by Victoria Herrera, Lisa Chikiamco, and Cid Reyes; The Life and Art of David Medalla, 2014, by Petty Benitez-Johannot; The Hypertext of HerMes, 2014, by Judy Freya Sibayan; The Life and Art of Isabelo Tampinco, 2014, by Santiago Pilar; and Roberto Chabet, 2015, edited by Ringo Bunoan.

Significant publications on Philippine ancient art came out based on new findings in archaeology. The National Museum publication Faces from Maitum: The Archaeological Excavation of Ayub Cave, 1996, authored by Eusebio Dizon and Rey Santiago and edited by Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton, broadens our understanding of ancient pottery with anthropomorphic designs. Establishing the links of Philippine art to Austronesian culture is exemplified in Paths of Origin: The Austronesian Heritage, 2011. Similarly, the seminal exhibit Philippines: Archipel des Échanges (Philippines: An Archipelago of Exchange), 2013, at the Musée du quai Branly in Paris, France, considered a landmark exhibit of Philippine artifacts in the possession of museums abroad, produced an exhibit catalog of the same title. Publications on the importance of gold in precolonial culture are seen in Florina Capistrano-Baker, John Guy, and John Miksic’s Philippine Ancestral Gold, 2011, published by the Ayala Foundation, and Ramon Villegas’s Ginto: History Wrought in Gold, 2004, based on the collection of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

Research on traditional art flourished with the publications of Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton’s A Heritage of Saints, 1979, and Philippine Religious Carvings in Ivory, 1983; Robert Lane’s Philippine Basketry, 1986; the Ayala Museum’s Pamanang Pilak (Silver Heirlooms), 1990; Sinaunang Habi: Philippine Ancestral Weave, 1991, authored by Marian Pastor-Roces with the photography of Dick Baldovino and Wig Tysmans; Norma Respicio’s Our Pattern of Island, 2003, and Journey of a Thousand Shuttles, 2014; and Elmer Nocheseda’s Palaspas: An Appreciation of Palm Leaf Art in the Philippines, 2009. Notable examples of publications on Philippine dress through the centuries are Salvador F. Bernal and Georgina R. Encanto’s Patterns for the Filipino Dress: From the Traje de Mestiza to the Terno (1890s-1960s), 1992; Patis Tesoro’s The Art of Embellishment, 1994; Jose Moreno’s Philippine Costume, 1995; Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s Jamming on an Old Saya, 1995; Slim’s, 2013; and Gino Gonzales and Mark Higgins’s Fashionable Filipinas, 2015.

Publications of journals, such as Transit and Pananaw: Philippine Journal of Visual Arts, contributed to the discussion of contemporary art. Academic journals, which employ interdisciplinary approaches in studying art, also published articles on art such as Kritika Kultura, Philippine Humanities Review, Diliman Review, and the Art Studies Journal. Textbooks on art and the humanities led to publications of Ang Sining sa Kasaysayang Filipino (Art in Philippine History), 1991; Art and Society, 1997; Sining at Lipunan (Art and Society), 1997 and 2014; and CHED Handbook for the Humanities: Art and Society, whose authors are from the Department of Art Studies, University of the Philippines Diliman.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez, Roberto G. Paulino, and Nicanor G. Tiongson

 

Collection and Archives

Art collections and archives are important resources in the writing of art history. Art collections in state institutions, such as the National Museum of the Philippines, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), Government Service Insurance System, Malacañan Palace, and CCP, invariably assume the category of heritage, implying the representative power of art to become material markers of identities. Archaeological, ethnological, and fine arts collections are kept by the state as purveyors of the historical past and rich diversity of cultures in the Philippines. This is exemplified by the National Museum collection pertaining to ancient pottery, as well as the boat-making tradition, which elucidates the maritime culture of the Philippines in precolonial times. The textile designs and wood carvings preserved through conservation methods also help art scholars in cross-cultural research across the Asian region. The gold and pottery collections of the BSP are significant as they illustrate the ubiquity of these materials in precolonial times.

Collections in museums abroad, such as the Smithsonian, Musée du quai Branly, University of Chicago, Lilly Library of the University of Indiana, and various museums and archives in Spain, hold important artworks, artifacts, and documents pertaining to Philippine art, including bulol sculptures, woven traditional textiles, jewelry and beads, and the Boxer Codex. The Asia Art Archive is a resource for the study of contemporary art across the Asian region.

 

The study of religious art during the Spanish period is represented by the ecclesiastical collections of the Intramuros Administration, University of Santo Tomas, Archdiocesan Museum of Manila, and San Agustin Church Museum. Villa Escudero in Tiaong, Quezon, houses a collection of religious artifacts such as retablos, santos, and church furniture.

Private museums and art collections are significant resources in the study of Philippine art. Fine art collections in the Lopez Museum, Ayala Museum, Yuchengco Museum, as well as collections endowed to universities, such as the Ateneo Art Gallery and the UP Jorge B. Vargas Museum, help in the study of art, especially the 19th century, the American period, and modern and contemporary art. Important private collections are those of Leandro V. Locsin, Luis Ma. Araneta and Eleuterio M. Pascual. A significant private collection is that of Paulino and Hetty Que, which includes religious art, santos, ivory, furniture, salakot, and an immense collection of paintings from the 19th century, works by National Artists and contemporary artists. Thematic exhibits have been done based on the Paulino Que collection. Other important collections are the Purita Kalaw-Ledesma collection, the art collection of Dr Joven Cuanang at the Pinto Art Museum, and the Roberto T. Villanueva ceramic collection, which are exhibited at the Ayala Museum.   Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz

article.value: Sections

The process of learning and understanding art is seen through the lens of art education, art scholarship and art criticism, and access to art collections and archive. The circulation of knowledge between these domains contributes to the discourse of art in every period in art history. The process of learning art through institutions in society, such as the community, schools and universities, church, state, and museums, contributes to how art is defined and valued at different contexts.
Art Education and Academe

Broadly conceived, art education is the learning and teaching of knowledge and skills in the visual arts not only to art students at the tertiary level but also to publics of diverse ages and talents. It includes instruction in the fine arts such as drawing, painting, and sculpture as well as media arts and crafts like advertising, furniture, and pottery. It may be conducted formally in school at different grade levels, or informally through workshops and apprenticeship.

The latter is the case among many Philippine ethnolinguistic groups. Traditions in art forms such as weaving, pottery, basketry, carving, jewelry making, and metalwork are passed on within a family or community. A young girl from the Cordilleras, for instance, learns how to spin, dye, and weave from her own mother or grandmother. In doing so, some places have become associated with particular products: Ilocos is known for its burnay and abel (blanket); Paete, Laguna, for wood carving; and Basey, Samar, for its colorful mats.

Conversely, artistic customs may disappear due to dearth and death of practitioners within a community. To address this, the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or National Living Treasure Award program was legislated in 1992 to give state recognition and support to traditional folk artists who exhibit technical and artistic excellence. Awardees are tasked to pass on their artistic traditions to their peoples in order to promote and preserve cultural heritage through the establishment of the School of Living Traditions in their communities.

The apprenticeship system likewise characterized art education during the 16th-18th centuries. Spanish missionary-artists opened workshops in their conventos (parish houses) in Intramuros and were sent to mission territories to instruct indios (Christianized native) and the Chinese on how to paint and sculpt religious images in the Western manner. Prints, especially from Flanders and Northern Europe, served as models for painting and sculpture and facilitated acquaintance with the European iconographic tradition. These religious images were made to adorn churches and to illustrate the teachings of Christianity, the major patron of the arts. By the same token, the typographic press—introduced by the friars by the early 17th century—produced devotional books, catechisms, dictionaries, estampas (large holy pictures), estampitas (small holy pictures), grammars, maps, and sermon collections. Like in painting and sculpture, knowledge in engraving and printing was transmitted to an apprentice or disciple who worked closely with a master to learn about the medium.

A more formal training in the visual arts emerged in the 19th century when the Academia de Dibujo, the first Manila art academy, was established in 1823 by the Real Sociedad Economica de Amigos del Pais. Its teacher and director Damian Domingo opened it to everybody, whether Spaniard, mestizo, or indio. Hitherto, many Filipino painters were either self-taught or learned informally from clerics. Domingo and the Real Sociedad also published Elementos de Perspectiva (Elements of Perspective) in 1828, positively indicating its academic orientation.

The first art academy, however, closed in 1834 due to lack of funds. Revived in 1850, its successor was patterned after the Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid where its directors had studied. Among the courses offered were modeling, figure drawing, drawing from life, and drawing from masterpieces. This learning-by-imitation model called for a museum to enable students to copy sculptures and paintings.

Initially a school for drawing and painting, the academia later added courses in engraving, lithography (1889), and sculpture (1893). Regardless of the course, learning was measured by a progressive mastery of simple to complex tasks. Drawing, believed to be the foundation of painting, was taught first. In anatomy classes, a student proceeded from drawing casts to painting live models. Incentives included awards, exhibits, as well as art scholarships to the Spanish peninsula. Among the notable products of the academy were Lorenzo Rocha, who later assumed co-directorship of the school after completing its first art scholarship to Spain, as well as Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo and Juan Luna.

The academia dissolved in 1898 with the change in colonial government from Spain to the United States. No formal art academy operated until the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts (UP SFA) opened in 1909. During the interval, artists like Teodoro Buenaventura, Fabian de la Rosa, and Rafael Enriquez offered private lessons in their studios.

article.value: Partly due to the efforts of the Asociacion International de Artistas organized by Enriquez, an escuella de bellas artes (school of fine arts) was reestablished and was attached as a charter unit of the University of the Philippines (UP). Enriquez served as the SFA’s first director. Majority of its founding faculty, like Buenaventura, Joaquin Herrera, Miguel Zaragoza, and de la Rosa, were instructors and/or graduates of the Academia de Dibujo. The UP SFA reproduced the European academic orientation of the latter, including the atelier and concours system. Instructions, such as life drawing classes, were given to groups of 20-35 students under a particular instructor. At the end of each semester, an exhibition was held and prizes were awarded. Five-year certificate courses in painting, sculpture, and engraving were offered; students were admitted via competitive examination.

Among the eminent early graduates were Fernando Amorsolo and Guillermo Tolentino, both of whom were soon invited as faculty and later assumed directorship of the school. Their lofty stature and influential romantic realist style closely identified the UP SFA with academism until the late 1950s.

In contrast, the fine arts and architecture program of the University of Santo Tomas (UST) was associated with modernism. It opened in 1930 with Victorio Edades as director. Notable modernists, including Carlos Francisco, Diosdado Lorenzo, Vicente Manansala, and Galo Ocampo, were invited by Edades to teach at UST. In 1938, Edades, Lorenzo, and Ocampo also established the Atelier of Modern Art in Manila. The distinction between the so-called conservative and modern art, which was applied by the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) in its painting categories from 1949 to 1955, was likewise implemented in the Shell National Students Art Competitions from 1953 to 1961. Most UP students won the prizes in conservative art while UST students garnered majority of awards in the modern category.

By the second half of the 20th century, other fine arts programs and organizations began to be established. In 1950, the Fine Arts Department of the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) was organized by Araceli Limcaco-Dans who later also co-founded with Brenda Fajardo the Philippine Art Education Association in 1968. The University of the East School of Music and Arts was established in 1964 with Pablo Victoria and Florencio Concepcion among its early directors. Far Eastern University opened its Institute of Architecture and Fine Arts in 1970 with Galo Ocampo as head of the Department of Fine Arts. Outside Manila, Martino Abellana was the prominent faculty in UP Cebu.

The fine arts curriculum also expanded in terms of course offerings and degree programs. A bachelor of fine arts major in advertising began to be offered by most of the aforementioned schools as well as by the College of Holy Spirit, the Far Eastern Air Transport Incorporated, and the Eulogio “Amang” Rodriguez Institute of Science and Technology, among others. Moreover, courses, if not degrees, in animation, art management, photography, video production, interior and industrial design have since been introduced.

Although often discussed in terms of instruction in skill courses, art education further includes the teaching of history, appreciation, and criticism of art. As early as 1912, the UP SFA administered a course in theory and history of art for its fourth year students. Vicente Alvarez Dizon taught drawing and art appreciation at the National Teachers College and lectured on history of art at the UP SFA from 1929 to 1941 and 1940 to 1947, respectively. From 1953 to 1960, Fernando Zobel lectured at Ateneo de Manila University (AdMU) in courses such as Introduction to Contemporary Painting, where he taught students how to look at painting as an artist might. In 1955, the UP College of Liberal Arts offered a course titled Humanities I, which included formal analysis of Western music and visual arts. By school year 1960-61, it became a required course for every UP student when it was incorporated into the general education program of the state university. Like Zobel, Humanities I treated art as a human(izing) experience rather than technical acquisition. Leopoldo Yabes, a proponent of the humanities program in UP, clarified that the humanities are intellectual disciplines, not vocational studies. Arts appreciation has since become a core course in the general education curriculum at the tertiary level.

Art education was likewise integrated in the curriculum of many primary and secondary schools. An early exponent was Dizon, author of Art Education and Appreciation, 1934, who advocated its inclusion to awaken an aesthetic sense in the early life of the youth. In 1941, the Bureau of Public Schools issued a Course of Study in Art Education for Elementary Schools. This was reportedly the first mention of “art education” as a subject. Hitherto, during the early American colonial period, “drawing” was the focus and nomenclature used in the study of art, which started as early as 1915 with the publication of Freehand Drawing for Primary Grades by the Department of Instruction. In 1963, Dans, who earlier developed the PWU Department of Fine Arts, also reorganized the art program of the Ateneo Grade School. Pablo Victoria wrote Art in the Elementary School, 1959, and Art Activities in the Elementary School, 1966. The Philippine High School for the Arts was established in 1977. Among the directors of this government-run school for artistically gifted students was another artist cum art educator Virginia Flor-Agbayani.

Workshops and internship programs facilitated by individual artists, art groups, institutions, and galleries are also venues for education in the arts. Manuel Rodriguez Sr conducted printmaking workshops during the 1960s, which was continued by Virgilio “Pandy” Aviado and younger members of the Printmakers Association of the Philippines. Nelfa Querubin in Iloilo, Tessy and Jon Pettyjohn in Laguna, the de Guzman family and Ugu Bigyan in Laguna teach pottery in their respective studios. Institutions like the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and the Lopez Museum provide on-the-job training to student volunteers in the various aspects of museum work.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, with notes from Roberto G. Paulino
Art Criticism

Aside from art education, another aspect in the production of knowledge in art is criticism. As distinguished from art history, art criticism is the evaluation of the artistic merits, historical significance, and cultural impact of artworks. It normally entails an ability to discern quality and skill in works, as defined by particular standards or canons of taste common to a time or place.

As a modern professional public practice, art criticism came to be increasingly allied in the 19th and 20th centuries with commodity market forces and their connection to the monitoring of changing trends in taste and fashion.

The speeches of Jose Rizal and Graciano Lopez Jaena at the banquet in honor of Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo provide one of the earliest examples of art criticism. According to Rizal, the gold and silver medals of Luna’s Spoliarium and Hidalgo’s Las Virgenes Cristianas Expuestas al Populacho (Christian Virgins Exposed to the Populace) at the 1884 Madrid Exposition demonstrated that genius can be found in all countries, thereby supporting the campaign for political equality.

During the American period, debate between conservative art and modern art stimulated critical writing about the nature of art. Artists and writers active in the debates included Edades, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Ariston Estrada, Salvador Lopez, Federico Mangahas, Ignacio Manlapaz, Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil, Tolentino, A.B. Saulo, and Jose Garcia Villa. The debate continued after World War II after the results of the inaugural 1948 AAP painting competitions led to the published exchanges between Edades and Tolentino.

By the 1950s, a new group of critics emerged and further broadened the support for modernism. This group included Aurelio S. Alvero, Francisco Arcellana, Leonidas Benesa, Ricaredo Demetillo, and Emmanuel Torres. Alvero, who used the pseudonym Magtanggol Asa, wrote the monograph of the First Exhibition of Non-Objective Art in Tagala presented by the Philippine Art Gallery (PAG) in 1953. Benesa and Torres, who were products of Ateneo and the Zobel lectures, as well as Arcellana and Demetillo, who were faculty members at the UP Department of English, were all winners in the AAP art criticism contest. Launched in 1954, the contest also lists critics Jolico Cuadra, Alice Guillermo, Cid Reyes, Reuben Cañete, and Ronald Achacoso as awardees.

The growing trend in the 1960s toward abstraction gave rise to questions of national identity vis-à-vis internationalism. In 1972, some of these art reviews first published in periodicals were compiled by Alice Coseteng in Philippine Modern Art and Its Critics. Aside from Benesa and Torres, other critics and book authors active in the 1970s were Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Alfredo Roces, and Paul Zafaralla. In the 1980s, Benesa, Angel de Jesus, and Guillermo also maintained regular art columns.

The relationship between the artist and critic is a perennial issue. A panel discussion on “The Role of the Critic” was organized by the Metropolitan Museum in 1990. An art criticism workshop facilitated by the UP Department of Art Studies was sponsored by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 1998. Competition and workshops continue with institutional support. Since 2009, UST conducts the J. Elizalde Navarro National Workshop in the Criticism on the Arts and Humanities. In 2014, the Metrobank Foundation added an art criticism competition to its visual arts program in painting, sculpture, interior design, and architecture, called Alice Guillermo Art Criticism Award. Also in 2014, an award called the Ateneo Art Awards–Purita Kalaw-Ledesma Prize for Art Criticism was instituted by the Ateneo Art Gallery and the Kalaw Ledesma Foundation Inc.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz
Art Scholarship

Art scholarship is the systematic study of artworks, artists, and visual art forms. It consists of related disciplines such as art history, which traces the development of art within a social, cultural, and historical context; art theory and aesthetics, which discuss the theoretical underpinnings of art; and connoisseurship, which includes authenticating particular works. Art scholarship also involves art education and art criticism.

Art scholarship in the Philippines properly belongs in the postwar period. This period also saw the rise of galleries and the necessary documentation of works exhibited. The war years saw the printing of two catalogues on individual art collections: Paintings by Filipino Artists, 1943, on the art collection of Jorge B. Vargas; and Art in Tagala, 1941, on the Aurelio Alvero collection.

The year 1958 saw the beginning of art scholarship with the publication of Art of the Philippines 1521-1957, edited by Winfield Scott Smith III. This was the only extended study of Philippine art until the publication of Art in the Philippines, 1964, by Dominador Castañeda, a painter and teacher at the UP College of Fine Arts.
Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla, founder of the Philippine Art Gallery, also published some of the first writings on art later compiled for the seventh anniversary brochure of the PAG.

Seminal essays on Philippine culture were published in the 1960s in the journal Philippine Studies. Among these was Zobel de Ayala’s essay on the santo, which was later expanded to Philippine Religious Imagery, 1963, a survey of Spanish colonial religious culture based on extensive private collections.

Benesa wrote a shorter historical survey for the National Museum, which also published a series, Aspects of Philippine Culture, 1967-68, which included monographs on indigenous arts, music, architecture, and modern painting. These were written by leading experts of the time, among them William Beyer, Galo B. Ocampo, and Antonio Molina.

For its fourth issue in 1966, the Humanities journal of the University of the Philippines included articles by Josefa Lava, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Virginia Moreno, Napoleon Abueva, Abdulmari Imao, and Ricaredo Demetillo on the visual arts.

The next important survey of the arts appeared as part of The Filipino People, a 10-volume series compiling writings by different authors and published by Grolier Encyclopedia in 1981. The volume on Philippine art, edited by Felipe de Leon Jr, presented the arts in the context of history and took advantage of scholarly developments up to 1971. Improved color printing technology later gave rise to art publications—meaning, books that combined technically competent photographs with substantial text. In the 1970s, art publishing became a phenomenon, starting with Manuel D. Duldulao’s Contemporary Philippine Art, 1972, containing informative material and good color reproductions that stimulated the art market. A survey from the 1970s was Julian Dacanay’s Trends Report, published as a mimeographed text and then later as part of Ethnic Houses and Other Essays, 1990.

In the 1970s, books on art that combined criticism with history were published by the Bureau of National and Foreign Information. These include Torres’s Ang Kiukok Drawings, 1975, and Aguilar Cruz’s Luna, 1975.

Combining art history and connoisseurship, Santiago Pilar wrote an exhaustive work, Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter, 1980, published by the Eugenio Lopez Foundation. A specialist on old masters, Santiago Pilar also did a book on the Vargas collection at UP and on Domingo Celis. In 1998, Jun Terra published a book titled Juan Luna Drawings: The Paris Period, documenting the collection of Dr Eleuterio M. Pascual. In 1998, Alfredo Roces published the first book on Hidalgo, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo and the Generation of 1872. Both Luna and Hidalgo were the subjects of a show and an accompanying bilingual catalogue, Oro Plata (Gold Silver), at the Metropolitan Museum in 1989.

While Jaime Laya was governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), the bank published, beginning 1981, its Kayamanan (Wealth) series of books: on its painting collection written by Torres, on antique gold jewelry by Ramon Villegas, and on ceramics by noted collectors. The BSP had gathered an impressive collection of 19th-century paintings of various forms and styles, from the miniaturist painting of the first half of the 19th century to the academic paintings of Luna and Hidalgo. A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces, 1986, was intended to be a teaching tool, which contains a handbook of essays on specific works by various scholars and 60 full-color reproductions printed on separate heavy-stock paper. In 2001, Laya himself authored the book Letras y Figuras (Letters and Figures).

article.value: These art books were supplemented by art publications that appeared in the 1970s and 1980s. One of these was Archipelago, a monthly magazine that appeared from 1974 to 1981 and which featured articles on old and contemporary masters, accompanied by color reproductions of their works. This magazine served as training ground in art criticism for young practitioners. A short-lived venture was the magazine Gallery Hopper. More recent publications featuring the arts are the Philippine Quarterly of Culture and Society; Philippine Studies of AdMU; and Arts Monthly and, later, Kultura magazine of the CCP.

A contribution to scholarship was the 10-volume Filipino Heritage, 1978, which contained short articles on art forms among the many articles that touched on all aspects of the Philippines. Lavishly illustrated, it was a treasure trove of visual data on the arts. This was followed later by the survey People and Art of the Philippines, 1981, by Gabriel Casal and others, published in connection with an exhibit held at the Museum of Cultural History of the University of California in Los Angeles. Another survey, Philippinische Malerei (Philippine Painting), was published in 1970 in connection with an exhibit in Germany.

Private individuals and foundations funded books, such as Paras-Perez’s Tolentino, 1976; Manansala Nudes, 1989; Sanso: Art Quest between Two Worlds, 1988; and Zobel, 1990. Paras-Perez also published a number of brochures on the early modernists for the Galerie Bleue. In The Filipino Nude, 1977, Alfredo Roces did a survey of the nude from the Spanish period to the present. He also did Amorsolo, 1975, and Sanso, 1976, as well as Philippine Cartoons 1900-1941, 1985, the latter co-authored with historian Alfred McCoy. Angel de Jesus, a member of the prewar Veronicans, continued to write on art in his columns and came out with a book, Hernando R. Ocampo: The Artist as Filipino, 1979. Earlier, Beatrice Harding’s Survival through Art, 1974, documented the development of the art of printmaker Manuel Rodriguez Sr.

Kalaw-Ledesma and Amadis Ma. Guerrero collaborated on the books Struggle for Philippine Art, 1974, and Edades, National Artist, 1979. Kalaw-Ledesma later drew from her large collection of primary sources to produce an originally designed book on the PAG. Benesa’s Okir, 1982, focused on printmaking, which has its roots in indigenous wood carving. A book on religious prints, The Filipino Engraving, 1980, was put together by a number of specialists, including the historian Jesus Merino, Paras-Perez, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya. The book had the added value of reproducing prints from copperplates hitherto unknown and stored in the UST Museum. Paras-Perez also wrote the book Manansala, 1980.

In the 1980s, public interest in art was maintained through regular columns written by Benesa, de Jesus, and Guillermo, among others. Guillermo also came out with Mobil Art Awards, 1980; Social Realism in the Philippines, 1987; Blanco, 1987; Alfredo Carmelo: His Life and Art, 1990; Cebu: A Heritage of Art, 1991; and the National Museum Visual Arts Collections, 1992. From Anito to Assemblage, 1991, by Guillermo and others, was published in conjunction with a retrospective of sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. Reyes wrote a book on Ben Cabrera in Etchings 1970-1980, 1986, and later compiled his interviews of various painters and sculptors into Conversations on Philippine Art, 1989. Art critic and scholar Paul Zafaralla came out with a book on the art educator Pablo Victoria, 1986; collaborated with Virginia Ty-Navarro on a work Carlos V. Francisco: The Man and Genius of Philippine Art, 1985; and also co-authored a book on Legaspi’s drawings. Books on significant Filipino artists were published in the 1990s, such as Kiukok: The Artist and His Work, 1991, by Esperanza Gatbonton; Legaspi: The Making of a National Artist, 1993, by Alfredo Roces; Exploding Galaxies: The Art of David Medalla, 1995, by Guy Brett; and A Sense of Serenity: Anita Magsaysay-Ho with Twelve Young Poets, 1996, by Charlson Ong.

In early 1993 the Crucible Workshop published Art Philippines edited by Juan T. Gatbonton, Jeannie E. Javelosa, and Lourdes Ruth R. Roa. It covers painting and sculpture from the Spanish colonial to the contemporary period. The writers are Benesa, Zafaralla, Torres, Guillermo, Reyes, Luciano Santiago, and Cesare Syjuco.

The CCP, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and the National Museum have been crucial in exhibitions of the visual arts. These are often accompanied by substantial catalogues. One of the CCP’s important projects has been the Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art) series of 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson. The first seven monographs were later put together into an illustrated coffee-table book by the editor. Later, Tiongson also edited the 10-volume CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994, which dedicated one whole volume to the visual arts, edited by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Alice Guillermo, and Santiago Pilar. CCP also published Igkas-Arte: The Philippine Arts during the Spanish Period, 1998.

In 1998, Discovering Philippine Art in Spain was published to commemorate the centennial celebration of the proclamation of Philippine independence, presenting artworks from the collection of various Spanish cultural institutions. The book includes discussion in ethnological art, Muslim military art, Christian art, and secular art, written by Jose Maria Cariño, Felice Sta. Maria, Brenda Fajardo, Abraham Sakili, Regalado Trota Jose, and Santiago Pilar.

article.value: The commemoration of the anniversary of an art award-giving body yielded publications that reviewed the winners of art competitions, such as Ginto: 50 Years of the Art Association of the Philippines: 1948-1997, 1999, edited by Reuben Ramas Cañete, and Metrobank Foundations MADE of Gold, 2013, celebrating the 50th anniversary of the bank and the 30th year of the competition. Publications on art history offering new research and perspectives continued in the 1990s to the 2000s, spurred by the postcolonial studies and concepts of new art history, which is interested in the social forces that affect the production of art and the considerations of issues of social class, gender, race, and ethnicity in art historiography. These include Guillermo’s Image to Meaning: Essays in Philippine Art, 2001, which is a collection of essays on contemporary artists and the layered reading of their artworks, and Protest: Revolutionary Art in the Philippines, 1970-1990, 2001, which is considered an important contribution in establishing the history of the art of the protest movement in the Philippines; Patrick Flores’s Painting History: Revisions in Philippine Colonial Art, 1998, which offers the postcolonial perspective of resistance by the colonized in reading colonial art; Thelma B. Kintanar’s Self-Portraits: Twelve Filipina Artists Speak, 2000; Flaudette May Datuin’s Home Body Memory: Filipina Artists in the Visual Arts, 19th Century to the Present, 2002; and Eloisa May P. Hernandez’s Homebound: Women Visual Artists in Nineteenth Century Philippines, 2004, which explores the unwritten history of women artists in the Philippines; Ang Inukit na Kaalamang Bayan ng Paete (The Carved Folk Knowledge in Paete), 2005, by Brenda Fajardo, employing the interdisciplinary approach in studying folk art; and Abraham Sakili’s Space and Identity: Expressions in the Culture, Art and Society of the Muslims in the Philippines, 2003, which explores the role of Islamic beliefs and Southeast Asian links in the traditional art of the Muslim Filipino. New studies on the visual arts pertaining to the Japanese colonial period were published, such as Panahon ng Hapon: Sining sa Digmaan (Japanese Period: Art in War), 1992, by Marcelino Foronda, and Helen-Yu Rivera’s books on editorial cartoons during this period—namely, Patterns of Continuity and Change: Imaging the Japanese in Philippine Editorial Cartoons, 1930-1941 and 1946-1956, 2008, and A Satire of Two Nations: Exploring Images of the Japanese in Philippine Political Cartoons, 2010.

Books on significant Filipino artists were published in the 2000s, oftentimes coinciding with retrospective exhibitions of their works, exemplified by the release of Edades: From Freedom to Fruition, 2012, in connection with a retrospective exhibition on National Artist Victorio Edades at the CCP. Monographs published on the life and art of Filipino artists include Parallel Texts: Federico Aguilar Alcuaz with Rod Paras-Perez, 2005, by Rod Paras-Perez; Fabian de la Rosa and His Times, 2007, by Luciano Santiago; Inscapes: The Art of Agnes Arellano, 2008, by Alice Guillermo; The Life and Times of Damian Domingo, 2010, by Luciano Santiago; Immaterial: The Art of Augusto Albor and Abueva, both published in 2010, by Cid Reyes; The Life and Art of Botong Francisco and The Life and Art of Francisco Coching, both published in 2010, edited by Patrick D. Flores; Alter/(N)ations): The Art of Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, 2010, edited by Flaudette May Datuin; Carlos Villa and the Integrity of Spaces, 2011, by Theodore Gonzalves; The Life and Art of Lee Aguinaldo, 2011, by Victoria Herrera, Lisa Chikiamco, and Cid Reyes; The Life and Art of David Medalla, 2014, by Petty Benitez-Johannot; The Hypertext of HerMes, 2014, by Judy Freya Sibayan; The Life and Art of Isabelo Tampinco, 2014, by Santiago Pilar; and Roberto Chabet, 2015, edited by Ringo Bunoan.

Significant publications on Philippine ancient art came out based on new findings in archaeology. The National Museum publication Faces from Maitum: The Archaeological Excavation of Ayub Cave, 1996, authored by Eusebio Dizon and Rey Santiago and edited by Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton, broadens our understanding of ancient pottery with anthropomorphic designs. Establishing the links of Philippine art to Austronesian culture is exemplified in Paths of Origin: The Austronesian Heritage, 2011. Similarly, the seminal exhibit Philippines: Archipel des Échanges (Philippines: An Archipelago of Exchange), 2013, at the Musée du quai Branly in Paris, France, considered a landmark exhibit of Philippine artifacts in the possession of museums abroad, produced an exhibit catalog of the same title. Publications on the importance of gold in precolonial culture are seen in Florina Capistrano-Baker, John Guy, and John Miksic’s Philippine Ancestral Gold, 2011, published by the Ayala Foundation, and Ramon Villegas’s Ginto: History Wrought in Gold, 2004, based on the collection of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

Research on traditional art flourished with the publications of Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton’s A Heritage of Saints, 1979, and Philippine Religious Carvings in Ivory, 1983; Robert Lane’s Philippine Basketry, 1986; the Ayala Museum’s Pamanang Pilak (Silver Heirlooms), 1990; Sinaunang Habi: Philippine Ancestral Weave, 1991, authored by Marian Pastor-Roces with the photography of Dick Baldovino and Wig Tysmans; Norma Respicio’s Our Pattern of Island, 2003, and Journey of a Thousand Shuttles, 2014; and Elmer Nocheseda’s Palaspas: An Appreciation of Palm Leaf Art in the Philippines, 2009. Notable examples of publications on Philippine dress through the centuries are Salvador F. Bernal and Georgina R. Encanto’s Patterns for the Filipino Dress: From the Traje de Mestiza to the Terno (1890s-1960s), 1992; Patis Tesoro’s The Art of Embellishment, 1994; Jose Moreno’s Philippine Costume, 1995; Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s Jamming on an Old Saya, 1995; Slim’s, 2013; and Gino Gonzales and Mark Higgins’s Fashionable Filipinas, 2015.

Publications of journals, such as Transit and Pananaw: Philippine Journal of Visual Arts, contributed to the discussion of contemporary art. Academic journals, which employ interdisciplinary approaches in studying art, also published articles on art such as Kritika Kultura, Philippine Humanities Review, Diliman Review, and the Art Studies Journal. Textbooks on art and the humanities led to publications of Ang Sining sa Kasaysayang Filipino (Art in Philippine History), 1991; Art and Society, 1997; Sining at Lipunan (Art and Society), 1997 and 2014; and CHED Handbook for the Humanities: Art and Society, whose authors are from the Department of Art Studies, University of the Philippines Diliman.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez, Roberto G. Paulino, and Nicanor G. Tiongson
Collection and Archives

Art collections and archives are important resources in the writing of art history. Art collections in state institutions, such as the National Museum of the Philippines, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), Government Service Insurance System, Malacañan Palace, and CCP, invariably assume the category of heritage, implying the representative power of art to become material markers of identities. Archaeological, ethnological, and fine arts collections are kept by the state as purveyors of the historical past and rich diversity of cultures in the Philippines. This is exemplified by the National Museum collection pertaining to ancient pottery, as well as the boat-making tradition, which elucidates the maritime culture of the Philippines in precolonial times. The textile designs and wood carvings preserved through conservation methods also help art scholars in cross-cultural research across the Asian region. The gold and pottery collections of the BSP are significant as they illustrate the ubiquity of these materials in precolonial times.

Collections in museums abroad, such as the Smithsonian, Musée du quai Branly, University of Chicago, Lilly Library of the University of Indiana, and various museums and archives in Spain, hold important artworks, artifacts, and documents pertaining to Philippine art, including bulol sculptures, woven traditional textiles, jewelry and beads, and the Boxer Codex. The Asia Art Archive is a resource for the study of contemporary art across the Asian region.

The study of religious art during the Spanish period is represented by the ecclesiastical collections of the Intramuros Administration, University of Santo Tomas, Archdiocesan Museum of Manila, and San Agustin Church Museum. Villa Escudero in Tiaong, Quezon, houses a collection of religious artifacts such as retablos, santos, and church furniture.

Private museums and art collections are significant resources in the study of Philippine art. Fine art collections in the Lopez Museum, Ayala Museum, Yuchengco Museum, as well as collections endowed to universities, such as the Ateneo Art Gallery and the UP Jorge B. Vargas Museum, help in the study of art, especially the 19th century, the American period, and modern and contemporary art. Important private collections are those of Leandro V. Locsin, Luis Ma. Araneta and Eleuterio M. Pascual. A significant private collection is that of Paulino and Hetty Que, which includes religious art, santos, ivory, furniture, salakot, and an immense collection of paintings from the 19th century, works by National Artists and contemporary artists. Thematic exhibits have been done based on the Paulino Que collection. Other important collections are the Purita Kalaw-Ledesma collection, the art collection of Dr Joven Cuanang at the Pinto Art Museum, and the Roberto T. Villanueva ceramic collection, which are exhibited at the Ayala Museum.   Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz
