article.value: As encomiendas failed to produce the revenues expected, the system was replaced in the late 16th century by the more lucrative galleon trade. The religious were allowed space for their exports in the galleon. During the 17th century, encomiendas ceased to be viable sources of income, and haciendas took their place. Most were owned by the religious. Both the galleon trade and the haciendas produced funds for the church, which in turn were spent for their apostolates. From Mexico, the galleons brought back to the Philippines the situado, a subsidy in silver taken from the rebate from the galleon trade. The situado financed the running of the colony, including the church’s work.

Aside from these sources of income, the church received donations from pious persons. Called founders or benefactors, these persons paid for a building, a sacred vessel, or painting, or left behind a pious endowment to be administered by the religious or by a board composed of priests and lay people. For instance, it is recorded that the church of Antipolo of the 1630s was paid for by Gov-Gen Niño de Tabora; and the Misericordia Confraternity, an association founded to help widows of Spanish soldiers, had a fund administered by a board that looked after its increment and distribution. Fund-raising campaigns were also undertaken. Thus did the Jesuits raise funds to build the 1889 San Ignacio Church in Intramuros and the Recollects, the 19th-century convento (parish house) of Lacy, Siquijor.

It would be an exaggeration to call the church the sole patron of the arts. However, by the 18th century, when church building and decorating was in full swing, it certainly was the most important institution, eclipsing the state in its patronage and directly commissioning many artworks. From the 16th to the mid-19th century, art was in the service of religion and colonial expansion. Artistically inclined friars taught engraving, painting, and sculpture, as well as music and the manufacture of musical instruments. Through the instrumentalities of the 1750 Real Orden, and later the 1840s Comision Permanente de Censura, all artistic productions passed through strict friar supervision. Artists had to obtain ecclesiastical permission to function in colonial society. It is not clear if the guild system found in Europe and Mexico had a counterpart in 17th- and 18th-century Philippines. If there were guilds, church control would have been exercised through them.

The churches built all over the country became the immediate centers of art patronage. Local populations were mobilized for the construction of churches. Commissioned were paintings to cover the walls and altars, as well as religious sculptures or santos to grace the retablos. As the churches grew in wealth, other arts were employed, such as the use of silver and/or gold for the altar, the chalice and monstrance, the accessories of the saints, and the floral ornamentation called ramilletes, embroidery in gold and silver for church vestments and costumes of the santos. Religious engravings for novenas brought out the skill of local engravers who were also put to work in cartography. Well-known 18th-century maps are those of 1734 and 1744, commissioned by the Jesuit Murillo Velarde and engraved by the Tagalog printers Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay and Francisco Suarez.

The creation of paintings and other church ornaments required great skill. Centers of art appeared, such as Paete in Laguna for wood carving, as well as Vigan in Ilocos Sur and the districts of Santa Cruz, Quiapo, and Binondo in Manila for silvercraft and embroidery. Bohol was well known for its mats, some interlined with gold thread and used as carpets in churches as well as for paintings and santos. Among the products that came from Binondo were ivory carvings. These were considered prestige products and found their way not only into churches but private homes. So sought was ivory that rich individuals bought these to give as gifts to friends and political lords in Mexico and Spain. Some Philippine ivories are now in Mexican and Spanish collections. In the active commerce between the Philippines and Mexico, exported aside from ivory were textiles—such as piña and sinamay, which was used to stiffen collars and cuffs—fans, and statues.

Because of the opening of the country to international trade in 1834 and the completion of the Suez Canal in 1869, which shortened sea travel between Spain and the Philippines, there emerged a new mestizo/native landlord-merchant class that benefited from cash-crop agriculture. This ilustrado (educated) class sent its young men to Europe to pursue various disciplines in the arts and the sciences, where they were exposed to liberal ideas, as well as the social amenities and cultural interests of the times. Church dominance in art patronage waned as the ilustrados emerged. Enjoying unprecedented wealth, they built the bahay na bato (house of stone) and furnished these in the European style, complete with Vienna chairs, mirrors, and various objets d’art.

During the 19th century, there was a fashion for miniature paintings, whether secular portraits or religious images, which brought out the talent of local artists. These were placed in gold lockets and given as prized gifts. To celebrate their social and economic ascendancy, the status-conscious ilustrados proceeded to commission portraits in the miniaturist style, which painstakingly recorded refinements of dress and jewelry, together with their treasured material possessions. The new entrepreneurs also commissioned letras y figuras (letters and figures), which artfully emblazoned their names in genre figures with scenes of urban streets and landmarks. Along with the letras was interest in tipos del pais (country scenes), which portrayed human figures dressed in local costumes in a variety of color and style, belonging to various social classes and representing diverse occupations. Patrons of the tipos could be foreign merchants who commissioned artists to paint and compile albums of tipos as souvenirs for home. Known for their album of costumes were the mestizo Damian Domingo in the 1820s and Justiniano Asuncion toward the middle of the century.

During this period of ilustrado dominance, santos commissioned for private altars became even more refined in material and artistic conception, richer and more elaborate in their embellishments. The santeros (makers of santos) enjoyed widespread patronage not only among the Manila elite but also among those in the provinces. Sculpture guilds catering to the rich sprang up in Quiapo and Santa Cruz. Among the widely patronized santeros were Leoncio Asuncion, Isabelo Tampinco, Mariano Madriñan, and Maximo Vicente.

Civil government, although not as active as the church, was also an important patron of the arts. Its patronage of the arts came to the fore when it sponsored the foreign education of artists. The best known of these pensionados were Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo who won gold and silver medals, respectively, at the 1884 Madrid exposition. Luna was commissioned by the Madrid government to do several paintings, among them La Batalla de Lepanto (The Battle of Lepanto). He also received commissions from the government in Manila. Both artists enjoyed the patronage of the elite, and Luna was in the good graces of the king of Spain, Carlos IV.

Three other government programs for fostering the arts were competitions, participation in international exhibits, and the establishment of an art academy. A competition was held for the cover design of the Augustinian Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas (Plants of the Philippines), a four-volume work published from 1877 to 1880. Agustin Saez, a Spanish art instructor, won over Hidalgo to do the illustrations. For the same book, Filipino artists like Hidalgo, Lorenzo Guerrero, Felix Martinez, Regino and Rosendo Garcia, Miguel Zaragoza, and others, collaborated in rendering aquarelles that were to be reproduced lithographically.

Another form of government patronage was the establishment of the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura in 1845, authorized by Gov-Gen Narciso Claveria and confirmed by Queen Isabela II. Authorized was a budget of 4,000 pesos for supplies and a monthly salary of 1,200 pesos per month for a professor of art. The academia replaced an earlier academy founded by Damian Domingo and was paid for by private sponsors. The academia lasted until 1891 when it was reorganized as the Escuela de Dibujo, Pintura y Grabado, which continued in existence until 1893.

The Spanish colonial period introduced all the characteristics of European patronage. Like the church movement in Europe, the state took a more active role in establishing academies which trained artists and ensured a style of art that would not threaten but enhance the power and prestige of the state.

At the fringes of colonial patronage, folk art emerged, sometimes challenging Spanish hegemony. Folk art was a form of artistic expression that drew from the traditions of farming communities, mainly still animistic, and the Christian tradition. Much folk craft often associated with fiestas, like pan de San Nicolas (embossed cookies), birhenan (cookies shaped like the Pakil Virgen de los Dolores), taka (papier-mâché toys), terra-cotta dolls, and parol (lanterns), were above ground and easily under the supervising eyes of colonial authority. But an underground folk expression in anting-anting (amulets) and esoteric oraciones (prayer booklets) emerged because they were believed to give power to their users. Anting-anting took many forms, but the more common ones were shirts emblazoned with mystic designs and cast metal medallions. The latter employed Christian symbols, like the cross and the eye of God, but surrounded by elements drawn from mystical writing. Oraciones were often illustrated with diagrams and symbolic images, and reading the prayers gave the reader powers according to the dictates of the text.

The establishment of American rule in 1901 saw another wave of patrons in the colonial officials and visitors in the country. In the spirit of the international expositions in vogue during the 20th century, these new patrons favored local color and the “exotic” in paintings, which they brought back to the United States as a reminder of their visit to the Philippines.

In the arts, the period was marked by the dominance of a stream of painting heavily influenced by Fernando Amorsolo based in the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts. UP was established by the American colonial government in 1908. The art school, founded in 1909, functioned as the official academy and a canon-making institution. The prolific Amorsolo, with his rural idylls of abundant harvests and the dalagang bukid or village lass, gained recognition and a sizeable patronage among American officials and the art-conscious sector of the local elite to whom owning an Amorsolo work was a status symbol. Amorsolo also won recognitions in art expositions abroad. During this time, clients commissioned painters directly as there were still no galleries for the exhibit and sale of artworks.

Amorsolo’s ascendancy was challenged by Victorio Edades’s one-man show at the Philippine Columbian in 1928. Freshly returned from abroad, Edades asserted modernist ideas and challenged the conservative and academic style of Amorsolo. The art scene was divided into the conservatives led by Amorsolo and Guillermo Tolentino, on the one hand, and the modernists, led by Edades, on the other. The public was made aware of this conflict by the press exchanges between the two camps.

During this period and the postwar era, two developments proved significant to the struggle for modern art. The Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), founded in 1948 by Purita Kalaw-Ledesma, instituted an annual competition for artists, thus encouraging the production of new works. The Philippine Art Gallery (PAG), founded in 1950 by Lydia Arguilla, became the first gallery to display and sell artworks.

The conflict between the conservatives and the modernists came to a head in the 1955 AAP annual art competition. The conservatives walked out because of the perception that the judges were biased for modern art. From this split grew what is now called “Mabini Art,” named after the street where many conservatives had their studios. Most of the conservatives had been trained in the UP School of Fine Arts under Amorsolo. In turn, they trained younger artists who remained under their influence.

The older conservative artists were Oscar Espiritu, Felix Gonzales, Crispin Lopez, and Felix Zablon. A younger generation consisting of Miguel Galvez, Gabriel Custodio, Romeo Enriquez, Serafin Serna, Cesar Buenaventura, and Ben Alano set up their studio in the Mabini area, and clients bought works directly from them. Most of them continued in the tradition of Amorsolo landscapes. Partly out of economic necessity, most were reduced to formula painting and to copying landscapes from imported art manuals. They continued to cater to foreign tourists and to local clients who sought less expensive paintings of familiar scenes to decorate their walls.

In time, the Mabini artists developed a system of production and marketing. Painters were grouped under a manager, often an artist himself, who obtained local and foreign commissions, imposed quotas and conditions on the painters, and paid them for their work. By the 1970s, some Mabini groups had branched out from Amorsolo-type paintings to other figurative and eclectic styles as well as into other media such as brass hammer-outs. But they remain decorative and facile in style. Also part of the Mabini art market were branches in Angeles, Pampanga, particularly near Clark Air Base where the painters catered to American clients who commissioned portraits.

With the ascendancy of modern painting and sculpture, a new patronage developed among urban, educated, and art-conscious Filipinos. They had supported the modernists in their struggles, and they became their new patrons. Galleries were subsequently set up for the display and sale of works. The pioneering PAG grew out of an advertising outfit and became the first venue for modern paintings. The owner, Arguilla, set into motion the practice of art criticism by writing and publishing some of the earliest writings on art. For print, Manuel Rodriguez Sr opened the Contemporary Arts Gallery, which also held printmaking workshops. Other privately owned spaces that were put up later include the Luz Gallery, Ayala Museum, and Marisan Gallery (now West Gallery), as well as the Heritage Gallery, Greenhills Art Center, Gallery One, Galerie Bleu, Galleria Duemilla, Hiraya Gallery, Liongoren Gallery, and Gallery Genesis. Aside from these, other venues for art are the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), with its several galleries (named after Juan Luna, Fernando Amorsolo, Guillermo Tolentino, Victorio Edades, and Carlos Francisco); the Metropolitan Museum of Manila; and the National Museum, with its several venues.

The Marcos period saw a boom in the art market. Imelda R. Marcos’s interest in the arts gave rise to patronage by her and a number of government officials and their wives. Among these officials was former Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) governor Jaime C. Laya. The BSP acquired works of 19th- and 20th-century masters, early moderns, and major contemporary artists, the latter through its reinvigorated annual acquisition program. These form what is now the BSP collection, a rich public repository of Philippine art regularly shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. The Casa Manila, under the Intramuros Administration, was also established to house artistic and traditional objects related to the Spanish colonial period. Other institutions, like private banks and other government offices, followed the trend. Notable for having accumulated old masters’ paintings were the Government Service Insurance System (GSIS), the United Coconut Planters Bank, and the Philippine Commercial and Industrial Bank, while the Multinational Investment Corporation invested in art masterpieces for resale.

Because of this vigorous art collecting, hitherto unknown 19th-century works were discovered and retrieved from dusty bodegas. The art market for these works was greatly stimulated, with prices skyrocketing to the hundreds of thousands. But it was the art dealers rather than the uninformed, often provincial owners, who derived much profit. Mrs Marcos also singled out artistic personalities in all fields to be special recipients of her favors. Part of the boost given the arts was the institution of the National Artist Award centered at the CCP. The attention given by the Marcos government to culture, however, tended to harness cultural and artistic activity to the service of the first couple.

Another factor that enlivened the art market was the building boom, which sought to project a prosperous image for the country so as to attract foreign investments. The buildings at the CCP Complex, particularly the Philippine International Convention Center and the Philippine Plaza Hotel, were built to host international conferences. Five-star hotels, such as the Manila Peninsula Hotel and the Mandarin Oriental, mushroomed at the height of the tourist drive. Most of these buildings were furnished with first-class accommodations, which included expensive paintings by well-known artists. Painters and sculptors were mobilized by dealers to fill these buildings with their works, with both artist and dealer reaping monetary rewards.

During this period, the fine arts developed as an industry. Its business potential was put to use by Malang’s Marisan cards, which made serigraph editions of works of well-known artists. Handmade paper reemerged as a craft and fine art form, fostered in part by the Design Center of the Philippines, which conducted seminars on papermaking. Handmade paper was seen as a potential source of income for economically depressed areas. The qualities of local fiber, like abaca, rice, cogon, and other grasses, were exploited. Handmade paper was produced in quantity by establishments like the Duntog Paper Mill of Baguio and Salay Paper.

Indigenous textiles also became the fashion. While handlooms in the Ilocos and Cordilleras produce textiles for daily use in traditional patterns, Narda Capuyan took traditional ikat as a starting point for innovative designs for tapestries, clothing, and fashion accessories. Manuel Baldemor introduced innovations in taka making in Paete by carving new molds. A parallel initiative in this regard was also undertaken by artist-members of Kasibulan working with women taka makers in Paete. Jose Joya teamed up with Anaware in Bacolod to make limited editions of plates bearing his signature figure drawings. Imelda Pilapil, experimenting on discarded objects (like drums, steel reinforcement) and also on glass and plastic, has made decorative yet functional furniture for export. Ramon Orlina created small glass sculptures sold in museum shops and specialty stores. Jerry Araos made furniture out of discarded railroad tires and parts of houses. Artists consciously tore down the traditional separation between fine art and functional crafts. In so doing, their works have been made accessible to both the wealthy and the middle class.

During this period, the first of a long series of coffee-table books on art appeared, and most were hard put in balancing art appreciation with a commodity orientation. Many of these books were meant to create a symbiotic and profitable relationship between art and advertising, as some art writers were regarded primarily as art promoters rather than critics and historians. Coffee-table books and gallery lectures on art management and collecting also stimulated public interest in the arts and boosted art sales. With the lively art market, patrons, both corporate and individual, strongly focused on the investment side of art collecting. This has resulted in more sales. In this climate, many artists were enticed by commercial opportunities, although the best of them survive even when art patronage is on a downswing.

Because of the perceived injustices and corruption of the Marcos regime, a new form of art emerged in the street art, put together by protesting groups and those engaging in nonprofit community projects. Cause-oriented groups cooperated with artist groups to produce murals and effigies mounted on jeepneys and trucks paraded during rallies. These are usually done without any artists’ fees, and the materials used consist of house paint and canvas donated by the groups and their sympathizers in labor, the academe, the professions, and members of the middle class.

During the early years of the Corazon Aquino administration, numerous art organizations sprang up overnight, indicating a lively art climate. The earlier commercial character gave way to a more socially and politically conscious art. As a result of numerous dialogues between the government and artists, the Presidential Commission on Culture and Arts (PCCA) was organized in 1987 to stimulate the development of art. Among the committees in the PCCA are those of the arts, heritage, and cultural dissemination. In 1992, the PCCA became the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, which by law was supposed to establish a national endowment fund to support the projects in arts and culture approved by its national committees.

The CCP, which was closely associated with Imelda Marcos, changed directions from being primarily a center for performing arts to being a coordinating center for all the arts and for all artistic traditions. At this juncture, it emphasized the Filipino artist over the foreign artists that the Marcos regime had favored. The CCP’s Coordinating Center for Visual Arts gave venue grants and some financial support to Manila-based and regional groups.

Today’s comparatively less centralized climate has enabled artists and various art agents to take greater initiative in managing their own practice. Private corporations and individuals remain the strongest patrons. Annual art contests sponsored by Metrobank, Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company, Petron, and Shell continue to give important incentives to artists. Despite the improving national economy and the rising local/international interest in the work of Filipino artists as demonstrated in the yields of regional art fair franchises and auctions, art practice and management remain competitive fields where only the strongest survive as new entrants emerge.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo
Art Market

The commoditization of art is exemplified by the trafficking of antiquities and art objects in both the local and the global art market landscape. The phenomena gave birth to art fairs, hedge funds, and hybrid partnerships across various art-world players, which heavily influenced the modes of valuation that operate in the Philippines. Amid these high-stake art agents, there would still indeed be downstream industries operating, such as forgeries and even itinerant peddlers literally vending frames on the street, coexisting in parallel to such aboveboard art market platforms. The vagaries latent in valuation disparities would first become most publicly prominent when Anita Magsaysay-Ho’s diminutive piece, In the Market Place, sold at a Christie’s auction in Singapore for a record 15 million pesos in 2008. Earlier, the GSIS acquired Juan Luna’s Parisian Life, 1892, for 42 million pesos in 2002.

Yet, despite the implementation of the National Cultural Heritage Act or Republic Act 10066 of 2009, which is the state’s attempt to enable the comprehensive registering of artifacts, particularly those en route outside the Philippines, the art industry remains largely unregulated. Its transactions are merely subject to general strictures applied to businesses across the board. Gallery commissions on sales made of artists’ works average at 50 percent of sale price with artists often being left to negotiate the burden of requested discounts and delayed or delinquent payments. Unlike in some international territories where resale or secondary market movement of works also accrues to shared benefits for artists or their heirs, similarly equitable arrangements do not play out in the local art world.

While the activity of foreign gallerists and curators coming into the Philippines began stirring up an arguable degree of professionalism and competitive fervor to retain talent in the early 2000s, what has most dramatically impacted the mode of production and degree of circulation of the works of some artists has been the slow but rising influence of both small and local, as well as large, franchise auction houses. The latter established themselves in the country through official representatives or through collaborative projects, as in the case of the recent teaming up of Christie’s with Art Fair Philippines (AFP) in 2015. Apart from AFP, which is organized by past officers of the Museum Foundation of the Philippines, at least two other major art fairs present themselves as being the most anticipated showcases of modern and contemporary art in the country: the Manila Art, initiated by the Bonafide Art Galleries Association, and the Sikat Pinoy National Art Fair, sponsored by the Department of Trade and Industry. As an act of philanthropy, parallel didactic-education events are usually part of the programming of these undertakings to balance content with business concerns, addressing the need of the visitors and especially the collectors.

These frequent interfaces between art industry agents and critical agents from the museum-academic sector have parallels in the way art historians are conscripted to produce the literature on art that affirms the choices made within the logic of business models peopled by both well-meaning enthusiasts but also savvy commodity traders. The aggressive push of auction house curators, for instance, has come at the cost of waning interest among artists to push into untried directions in art-making. Rather, artists are given advice based on business models, favoring a formulaic mind-set expressed in preferred scale, trend conformity, even type of figuration, in keeping with the notion of building a dependable brand possibly only accessible to a few. In contrast to the 1950s through the 1980s when auctions came largely as isolated attempts to do fund-raising benefits by the Art Association of the Philippines or by the gallery network that was for a time running a themed project called Art Manila, the current pace of monthly/quarterly auctions brings scouts right to the studios of artists who, instead of producing for exhibitions in museums or even their own galleries, are pressured to tick off orders from a preferred list of collectors or to headline the spread in upcoming fairs/auctions. Gallerists too have tended to exert their influence much earlier now in the still nascent career of artists as they have become staple presences on thesis or award panels if they are not avidly attending critique sessions and art award ceremonies to keep in step with industry developments.

On the other hand, parallel self-organizing being done by artists does continue to take the form of artist-run spaces or itinerant platforms, which at their global height in the 1990s succeeded in short-circuiting validation mechanisms by drawing the attention of less established collectors and still enterprising curators. These spaces and art platforms variably embrace alterity in their programming, with some merely providing a venue but others seeing to it that they serve the need of artists for places to converge, undertake workshops, organize discussions or transmedia projects. Such activities would not easily fit into the mode of operations of more mainstream and profit-oriented spaces. In some cases, art galleries might eventually appropriate these public engagement modalities to maintain relevance within the fluid parameters of the art world.   Written by Maria Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez
Awards

The enterprise of conferring awards covers a wide range of such symbols of validation as honors, grants, and residencies, commonly obtained by way of a competitive application or nomination procedure. While it is ostensibly about acknowledging achievement, it actually involves the manufacture of value. Prize-giving is an opportunity for art-world agents to advance and reinforce their claims to authority and legitimacy by advocating a certain aesthetic, endorsing specific practices, or drawing evaluative attention to a work of art.

This is not in any way to suggest, of course, that the act of awarding is, at its root and core, a futile, cynical one, no matter how vulnerable it may be to charges of commercialization, corruption, or obscurantism, and no matter how valid such charges may be—unfortunately so in situations, sadly ubiquitous, where accolades serve as shortcuts for cautious, incisive assessment; where they are construed as permanent guarantees of noteworthy performance; or where they are wielded as weapons by stakeholders, givers, jurors, funders, recipients, and critics among them, to coerce acquiescence or to quell resistance from others.
Awards in the field of visual arts are given to recognize individual accomplishment as well as to encourage excellence.

The earliest award received by a Philippine native was given by an institution outside the country. In 1868, Lorenzo Rocha received an honorable mention for El Sueño de Don Ronsiro (The Dream of Don Ronsiro) from the Madrid art exposition of that year.

One of the earliest local art competitions in the 19th century was that opened by the editor Domingo Vidal y Soler to select the best cover design for the deluxe edition of Fr Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas (Plants of the Philippines) in 1877. Prof Agustin Saez won first prize, and his student Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo won second. The Ayuntamiento de Manila subsequently awarded Hidalgo a scholarship in fine arts, after undergoing a competitive test. He was sent to Spain to pursue advanced studies at the Academia de San Fernando in Madrid.

The Sociedad Economica de Amigos del Pais de Filipinas gave awards to artists who contributed to Flora de Filipinas, one of whom was Regino Garcia y Baza. In 1879, the Liceo Artistico-Literario held a literary-artistic contest for which Jose Rizal submitted two entries: a poem, “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth), and the other a wooden bust of Cervantes. The prize was awarded to Telesforo Sucgang for his bust of Cardinal Cisneros. A nationwide artistic competition was held in Oct 1882 during the tercentenary celebration of Santa Teresa. On this occasion, Lorenzo Guerrero won a gold medal for Transverberacion de Santa Teresa de Jesus (Transfixion of Saint Theresa), and Felix Martinez won the silver medal. The year 1883 saw the Amsterdam International Exposition in which Paete sculptor Mariano Madriñan won first prize for his Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother). King Alfonso XII sent the diploma of honor to the winning sculptor through the governor-general in Manila.

The first important international competition in which Filipino painters won was held in Europe. This was the Madrid exposition of 1884 in which Filipino expatriate artists Juan Luna and Hidalgo won prizes. To qualify for the competition, the artists had to conform to its standards: oil on canvas, large-scale, subject drawn from classical antiquity, modeling with light and dark. Luna won the first gold medal for his large-scale canvas Spoliarium, and Hidalgo, a silver medal for Las Virgenes Cristianas Expuestas al Populacho (Christian Virgins Exposed to the Populace). Luna was awarded the first gold medal rather than the medal of honor, which was the highest distinction. The medal of honor in that 1884 competition was not awarded to any artist. There were talks that Luna was denied this distinction, not because of any artistic shortcoming but because he was not Caucasian. Even the king of Spain, Alfonso XII, with his warm congratulations of Luna, openly expressed his sympathies for Luna’s failure to receive the medal of honor. Later, because of growing public opinion critical of the jury, Luna was commissioned to do a large canvas, La Batalla de Lepanto (The Battle of Lepanto), which was unveiled by the Queen Regent Maria Cristina in 1887 and hung in the Senate conference hall. In 1886, Luna entered the Spoliarium in the Paris Salon, and the piece received another gold medal.

Luna and Hidalgo won in subsequent competitions. At the Exposicion General de las Islas Filipinas held in Madrid in 1887, Hidalgo won his first gold medal for La Barca de Aqueronte (The Boat of Charon). This painting also won for Hidalgo a diploma de honor (certificate of honor) at the Exposicion de Bellas Artes of Barcelona in 1891. In 1890, Luna became a lifetime member of the exclusive Societe Nationale des Beaux Arts of Paris, which allowed him the privilege of showing several paintings at the Champs de Mars without being screened by the board. As Luna won the grand prize at the salon for his Chiffonier (Rag Picker), he was entitled to this privilege. From then on, the artist’s paintings on exhibit would be labeled “Hors Concours” (H.C.) or “outside the contest” to indicate that the work was by an established artist and thus did not enter in competition.

In 1887, the Exposicion General de las Islas Filipinas took place in Madrid. The Philippine participation was managed by Vidal y Soler and Garcia y Baza, a Filipino artist and botanist who directed the building of nipa houses typifying native construction. Garcia himself won honorable mention for his painting depicting Philippine views and themes in this exhibit. In the same exposition, Rafael Enriquez, later to become first director of the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, won a medal for La Muerte de D. Simon de Anda (The Death of D. Simon de Anda), while Domingo Teotico won a bronze medal in sculpture. The following year, in 1888, Garcia also supervised the Philippine and Compañia Tabacalera exhibits in the Exposicion Universal de Barcelona where Isabelo Tampinco won a gold medal for his model depicting the sculptures and carvings of the new Jesuit church in Intramuros, the San Ignacio.

Besides the international expositions already mentioned, there were the Exposicion Internacional de Bellas Artes in Madrid in 1892, the Universal Exposition of Chicago in 1893, the Exposicion Artistica de Bilbao in 1894, and the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas in Manila in 1895. In 1895, even Filipino sculptors Isabelo Tampinco, Bonifacio Arevalo, Eulogio Garcia Velarde, and Eugenio Llerena won prizes. An earlier art competition held in Manila in 1892 was connected with the third centenary of San Juan de la Cruz. Teotico won second prize in sculpture in this fete. It is also to be noted that in these expositions, paintings and artworks constituted only a section; other sections consisted of agricultural exhibits featuring rice and woods, as well as local crafts—such as canes—in which Filipino artists also won prizes. For instance, a set of carved furniture by Teotico won a silver medal in the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas. Aside from these expositions, well-known painters like Hidalgo also participated in the regular salon exhibits of Les Champs Élysées in Paris.

In the 1902 Exposicion de Hanoi, the sculptor Arevalo won awards for his works, among them are portraits of the emperor and empress of Japan. Two years later, in 1904, the Universal Exposition of Saint Louis was held. The Philippine representation was displayed in a mock village occupying several hundred acres comprising settlements of various cultural groups. The artistic entries were given awards by the Philippine Exposition Board. There were two types of awards: overall collaboration and individual awards. Hidalgo received a gold medal for overall collaboration, while he received other golds, silvers, and bronzes for his individual entries. This was also the case for other artists like Felix Martinez, Miguel Zaragoza, and Fabian de la Rosa. De la Rosa won a gold medal for Planting Rice and a bronze medal for The Death of General Lawton, a historical scene commissioned by the American consul. Also in the Saint Louis exposition, Manila sculptor Llerena won a silver medal for his Huyendo del Fuego (Fleeing from the Fire), a wood carving of a woman and her children fleeing from a fire. It is interesting to note that in this exposition a work by sculptor Marcelo Nepomuceno was rejected because its subject of a Filipino woman brandishing a bolo against a lion and an eagle was considered too strongly nationalistic by the exposition board.

In 1908, the Primera Exposicion de Bellas Artes y Artes Industriales in Manila was sponsored by the Asociacion Internacional de Artistas de Manila to welcome an American squadron in its visit to the city. In this show, Llerena again won for two sculptures of tipos del pais, featuring human figures in local costume.

Also in 1908, the Liga Antipornografica held a literary-artistic competition in Manila in honor of Pope Pius X. Here Llerena won a silver medal for his carving of San Francisco Xavier. In the Panama International Exposition of 1915, a painting by Hidalgo, exhibited posthumously, won a gold medal. In the Philippine Exposition of 1925, Jose Caancan of Paete won first prize for his wooden bust of Gen Leonard Wood. During the American colonial period, medals were also awarded to the most artistic floats on Rizal Day celebrations and carnivals. One more exposition before World War II was the Golden Gate San Francisco World Fair and Exposition in 1939. For this occasion, pioneering modernists Victorio Edades, Galo B. Ocampo, and Carlos V. Francisco aka Botong Francisco were commissioned to do two murals.

During the Japanese occupation, 1942-45, an important aspect of the Japanese campaign was undertaken in art and culture. The Japanese occupational government, through the Kapisanan sa Paglilingkod sa Bagong Pilipinas, sponsored two art exhibits. Ricarte Puruganan’s Bullfight won first prize in the 1943 exhibition. Francisco won first prize for Angelus, second prize for Frugal Meal in the Fields, and third prize for Angono Fiesta in the 1944 exhibition.

After World War II, the first national art awards were instituted by the Art Association of the Philippines and the first AAP national art exhibition, which was also a competition, was held on 3 Jul 1948, the year AAP was founded at the National Museum on Herran St. The judges for this historic exhibit were Edades, the pioneering exponent of modern art; Fernando Amorsolo, the leading painter of the conservative academy; Francesco Monti, a sculptor; and Emilio Aguilar Cruz, one of the earliest art critics. All the winning entries were paintings. The following were the winners in this competition: Carlos V. Francisco, first prize for Kaingin; Demetrio Diego, second prize for Capas; Vicente Manansala, third prize for Banaklaot; Cesar Legaspi, fourth prize for Sick Child; Diosdado Lorenzo, fifth prize for Japanese Inhumanities; and Hernando R. Ocampo aka H.R. Ocampo, sixth prize for Nude with Candle and Flower.

The following year, 1949, was a busy year for the AAP, which held three competitions. Its second annual art exhibit was held on 4 Jul 1949 at the National Museum. The winners with their paintings were Cesar Legaspi, first prize for Gadgets; Romeo Tabuena, second prize for Agnus Dei (Lamb of God); Manuel Rodriguez Sr, third prize for Washing by the Creek; Legaspi, fourth prize for Planters; Victor Oteyza, fifth prize for Perfect State; Hugo Yonzon Jr, sixth prize for Squatters; Elias Laxa, seventh prize for Before the Storm; and Nena Saguil, eighth prize for Faith. The judges were Ricarte Puruganan, Demetrio Diego, H.R. Ocampo, and Bonifacio Cristobal. In addition to its annual, AAP held an exhibit competition in connection with the Boys’ Town Carnival. The winners were Cristobal, Puruganan, H.R. Ocampo, Manuel Galvez, and Katy Yatco. The third AAP-sponsored contest was the Manila Art Club art exhibition held on San Marcelino St in October. What was new in this contest was the division of the entries into two categories, conservative and modern, both further grouped by medium into oil and watercolor/pastel. Top winners for the conservative category were Laxa, Miguel Galvez, Romeo B. Rodriguez, Crispin Lopez, and Simon Saulog; those for the modern category were Puruganan, Legaspi, H.R. Ocampo, and Ramon Estella—with some winning more than one prize. The judges were Jack Y. Bryan, Anita Magsaysay-Ho, and Aurelio S. Alvero.

In 1950, the AAP held its annual in January, and a third semiannual art exhibition in the painting category in July as sponsored by the Manila Grand Opera House. As in the 1949 Manila Art Club exhibition, this fourth AAP annual exhibition at the Manila Trading and Supply Center on 24 Feb 1951 had entries divided into conservative and modern, with the additional category of sculpture.

The AAP also instituted special awards, one for Best Interpretation of Filipino Life to Non-Filipinos in drawing and watercolor, and another award in caricature. Juvenal Sanso won first prize in the conservative category for his work Sorcerer. The other winners were Rodolfo Herrera, Wenceslao Garcia, and Serafin Serna. Top winners in the modern category were Legaspi, H.R. Ocampo, and Galo B. Ocampo. The winners in sculpture were Mariano Edjawan, first prize; Napoleon V. Abueva, second prize; and Ramon Estella, third prize. The special award for Best Interpretation of Filipino Life to Non-Filipinos was given to H.R. Ocampo. Also in the same year, the AAP held its first separate sculpture show. The winners were Abueva, Anastacio Caedo, and Jose Alcantara. It had special awards for Best Filipino Interpretation of the Madonna, and Best Entry in Wood, Plaster, Metal, and other Media. Abueva won three prizes in this competition. The judges were Magsaysay-Ho, Gilbert Perez, Daniel Zamora, Pablo Antonio, and Maximo Vicente Jr.

The AAP annual art exhibitions reflected growing tension between the conservatives and the modernists who challenged the former’s dominance. The final break came at the eighth AAP annual exhibition held at the Northern Motors Showroom. Whereas in the regular exhibition the division between the conservatives and modernists was observed, this was not the case in the Rotary Golden Anniversary Awards, which had a separate contest co-sponsored by the AAP in the same venue. The Rotary Club had earlier approached the AAP and announced that it would give three cash awards, with a first prize of 2,000 pesos for the paintings or sculptures that would best reflect the Rotary themes of service, international brotherhood, and understanding. The winners were all modernists: Vicente Manansala, Galo B. Ocampo, and Manuel Rodriguez Sr. Thus conservatives walked out with their paintings from the exhibit hall, and put up their own exhibit at the Luneta and on Mabini St. This historic walkout proved that the modernists had finally gained ascendance. In subsequent competitions, the AAP often observed the following categories: painting and sculpture, with special awards in watercolor, graphic arts, and photography.

Several other award-giving bodies were instituted to honor Filipino artists, such as the Republic Cultural Heritage Awards. Among its awardees were JoseJoya, 1961; Manansala, 1963; Francisco, 1964; Federico Aguilar Alcuaz, 1965; ArturoLuz, 1966; Rodriguez Sr and Amorsolo, 1967; Lorenzo, 1970; and Roberto Chabet, 1972.

The Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP) first instituted the PAP annual national graphic arts competition in 1969. Among its grand prize winners up to 1972 were Manuel Rodriguez Jr, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Efren Zaragoza, Ivi Avellana-Cosio, and Raul Isidro. The competition thereafter was held intermittently.

The Mobil Art Awards started in 1980 with its first batch of winners: Joya, Danilo Dalena, Ang Kiukok, Romulo Olazo, and Mauro Malang Santos. In 1982 its awardees included Paz Abad Santos, Tam Austria, Prudencio Lamarroza, Lao Lianben, and Manuel Rodriguez Jr.

The Shell National Students Art Competition (SNSAC), launched in 1951, was halted during the tumultuous 1970s and was later revived in 1989 to commemorate Shell’s 75th anniversary. Among its awardees from 1956 to 1965 were Joya, Alcuaz, Ang Kiukok, Ong Bun Gian, Manuel Rodriguez Jr, Veronica Lim (Yuyitung), and James Ong Le Pho. The competition also recognized artists Lao Lianben, Danilo Dalena, Prudencio Lamarroza, Nestor Vinluan, Jonahmar Salvosa, Virgilio Aviado, Norberto Carating, Fernando Sena, Norma Belleza, Charito Bitanga, Tessie Dimayuga, and Mario Parial, among others.
Today, the SNSAC contest continues to attract students from top universities and colleges in the country with generous cash prizes, medals, certificates, and scholarship grants.

Considered “a stable ground to test the artistic aptitudes of new talents in art,” the Metrobank Foundation national painting competition, established in 1984, has actively contributed to the cause of supporting young Filipino artists. Called Metrobank Art and Design Excellence or MADE, it has since expanded its award categories to encompass works in oil, watercolor, sculpture, architectural design, and art criticism. From 1984 to 1987, the winners in mixed media category were Luis Hidalgo, Dindo Peralta, Raymon Maliwat, Alwin Reamillo, Nelson E. Ferraris, Noell EL Farol, Manuel K. Tan, Gabriel Barredo, Angelito L. Lopez, Arnaldo B. Mirasol, Joel Marayag Ferrer, and Robert Feleo. From 1988 to 2015, winners for the oil painting category were Antonio C. Leaño, Geronimo M. Tapales, Mark Justiniani, Eduardo M. Paredes, Ferdinand B. Montemayor, Ramon V. Villanueva, Norman B. Dreo, James C. Haresco, Godwin S. Nerona, Andres S. Barrioquinto, Mark A. Magistrado, Elmer R. In the watercolor category, winners from 1988 to 2015 were Ernesto M. Verroya, Wilfredo C. Aguino, Eduardo A. Santos Jr, Arvin Benjie S. Ramos, Magdiwang M. Jardiniano, Anthony E. Palomo, Ricardo G. Reyes, Wesley T. Valenzuela, Clarence M. Eduarte, Ernilo Z. Germino, Maria Dorothea S. Taniguchi, Richard I. Venacio, Rex S. Tatlonghari, Teodoro M. Peñaflor, Michael D. G. Gonzales, Randie M. Rodriguez, Chrisanto Aquino, Christopher Gomez, Darby Vincent Alcoseba, John Verlyn Santos, and Don Bryan Bunag. Winners in the sculpture category from 2004 to 2015 were Florence Sinco, Jan Leeroy New, Kelly Sonio, Harry Marc Gonzales, Elrine Vicaldo, Teodorico Cumagun III, Marc Vincent Cosico, Jonathan Dangue, Alexander Tee, Merlito Gepte, and Natalio Alob Jr. Since 2004, the Metrobank Foundation Prize for Achievement in Sculpture was instituted with the award given to Dan Raralio, Duddley Diaz, Peter de Guzman, Juan Sajid Imao, Salvador Joel Alonday, and Noell EL Farol.

Another corporate-driven art competition is the Philippine Long Distance Telephone (PLDT)–GTE Directories Publication Corporation telephone directory cover visual arts national competition. It is open to all students currently enrolled in any of the colleges of fine arts in Metro Manila universities. The competition has harvested works that graced the cover of the PLDT directory book since 1987.

The Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) of the Philippines, a yearly search for the 10 most outstanding young Filipino achievers, was founded in 1959 by the Manila Jaycees in cooperation with the Gerry Roxas Foundation. It is similarly committed to promoting leadership and exemplary innovation. Among the recipients were Abueva, 1959; Joya, 1961; Mauro Santos, 1963; Rodolfo Ragodon, 1964; Abdulmari Imao, 1967; Eduardo Castrillo, 1971; Manuel Duldulao, 1972; Raul Isidro, 1979; Pacita Abad, 1984; Cesare Syjuco, 1991; Juan Sajid Imao, 2001; Kenneth Cobonpue, 2003; Michael Cacnio, 2006; and Rajo Laurel, 2009. Some of the other shorter-lived award undertakings include those of the Amon Corporation and Remy Martin Philippines. More recently established corporate competitions include those of the Petron Corporation and the Philip Morris Group of Companies. These local ventures have also been complemented by more international initiatives that provide opportunities for artists to take on international residencies such as the Asian Cultural Council, Asian Art Network, and many other more modest artist-initiated residencies within the Philippines and abroad.

The Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Awards given by the city of Manila every 24th of June in celebration of the Araw ng Maynila (Manila Day) has honored several artists, such as Fernando Amorsolo and Guillermo Tolentino, 1963; Victorio Edades, Carlos Francisco, Antonio Llamas, Galo B. Ocampo, and Anastacio Caedo, 1964; Napoleon Abueva, 1965; Federico Alcuaz and Graciano Nepomuceno, 1966; Fabian de la Rosa and Ambrosio Morales, 1968; Diosdado Lorenzo and H.R. The CCP’s Thirteen Artists Awards was established by Roberto Chabet in 1970 to encourage a new generation of artists whose works showed recentness, innovativeness, and individuality. This was packaged as such in honor of the pioneering Thirteen Moderns. Up to 1980, the selection of awardees depended largely on the choices of then visual arts director Albano. The first batch of awardees in 1970 were Ray Albano, Angelito Antonio, Virgilio Aviado, Eduardo Castrillo, Benedicto Cabrera, Restituto Embuscado, Marciano Galang, Lamberto Hechanova, Jaime de Guzman, Noel Manalo, Ben Maramag, Manuel Rodriguez Jr, and Antonio Austria. In 1988 the new CCP democratized the selection by asking different groups to nominate candidates. The search was also widened to encompass different styles and highlight the excellence and maturity of artists’ works. Given every two years, it comes with a production grant, trophy, and group exhibition at the Bulwagang Juan Luna or Main Gallery. The following visual artists have received the award: Agnes Arellano, Roberto Feleo, Peter de Guzman, Pardo de Leon, Dan Raralio, Popo San Pascual, Jose Tence Ruiz, Gerardo Tan, 1988; Norberto Carating, Charlie Co, Julie Lluch Dalena, Antipas Delotovo, Leonilo Doloricon, Imelda Calipe-Endaya, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Renato Habulan, Sid Gomez Hildawa, R.M. de Leon, Pablo Baens Santos, Jean Marie Syjuco, Roy Veneracion, 1990; Paz Abad Santos, Nunelucio Alvarado, Manuel Baldemor, Fil Delacruz, Brenda Fajardo, Tommy Hafalla, Willy Magtibay, Onib Olmedo, Soler Santos, Lazaro Soriano, Cesare Syjuco, Sandra Torrijos, Roberto Villanueva, 1992; Elmer Borlongan, Noel Cuizon, Francesca Enriquez, Mark Justiniani, Antonio Leaño, Ferdinand Montemayor, Jonathan Olazo, Alwin Reamillo, Arlene Villaver, Edwin Wilwayco, 1994; Ronald Achacoso, Juan Alcazaren, Sari Raissa Lluch Dalena, Alfredo Esquillo Jr, Karen Ocampo Flores, Emmanuel Garibay, Leo Gerardo Leonardo, Neil Manalo, Bernardo Pacquing Jr, Claro Ramirez Jr, John Frank Sabado, Jose John Santos III, Katti Sta. Napay, Archie Oclos, Lynyrd Paras, and Shireen Seno, 2018.

The Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to artists for their contribution to the development of their art form or to regional culture, and to cultural workers for their efforts to develop the Philippine arts. While the award was first given in 1977, the guidelines were only established in 1988. Awards were given every year from 1989 to 1994, before becoming every three years. Among its past awardees in the visual arts were artists Luz, 1989; Legaspi and Imao, 1990; Joya, 1991; BenCab, 1992; Tony Velasquez, 1993; Malang Santos, 1994; Santiago Bose, 2004; Francisco Coching and Pitoy Moreno, 2008; Brenda Fajardo, 2012; and Roberto Chabet and Ben Farrales, 2015. AAP founder Purita Kalaw-Ledesma and the Talaandig School for Living Traditions also received the Tanging Parangal award in 1991 and 2015, respectively. In 1999, the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts were conferred to 100 Filipino artists and scholars who have strongly contributed in the development of Philippine art. Among the recipients were visual artists Napoleon Abueva, Fernando Amorsolo, Lydia Arguilla, Roberto Chabet, Danny Dalena, Araceli Dans, Fabian de la Rosa, Victorio Edades, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Brenda Fajardo, Botong Francisco, Jose Joya, Purita Kalaw-Ledesma, Cesar Legaspi, Juan Luna, Arturo Luz, Vicente Manansala, Nonoy Marcelo, Eduardo Masferre, H.R. Ocampo, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, and Guillermo Tolentino.

Apart from administering a variety of production and travel grants, alongside a mechanism for recognizing cultural workers and artists through the Diwa ng Sining awards, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) has, in the past, also run a cross artist-organization competitive grant called the Layag residency and an emerging artist exhibition grant called Sinugdanan. Starting 2001, the Gawad Alab ng Haraya (Alab ng Haraya Awards) and Dangal ng Haraya (Achievement Awards) were instituted by the NCCA to recognize the contributions of groups and individuals in the field of arts management and cultural work. Another government corporation award body is the Government Service Insurance System, which has been running an annual art acquisition mechanism through its own competition launched in 2004.

The Manlilikha ng Bayan or National Folk Artist Award was started in 1990 as a national tribute to master folk artists. Initiated by the Rotary Club of Makati-Ayala and the Cultural Center of the Philippines and supported by an interagency committee from the private and government sectors, it was first given to Kahhimngan Palatic for Cordillera ikat weaving, Rasid Laidan for Maranao brass casting, Magdalena Marte for piña weaving, Fidel Go for burnay pottery, Maluy Lasa Sambolani for Laminusa mat weaving, and Ely Arcilla for Paracale gold-jewelry making. Management of the awards has been passed onto the National Commission for Culture and the Arts through Republic Act 7355. The Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan (National Living Treasure Award) or GAMABA has been given to the following: Ginaw Bilog for surat Mangyan and ambahan poetry, awarded in 1993; Salinta Monon for Bagobo textile weaving, and Lang Dulay for Tboli tnalak weaving, both awarded in 1998; Darhata Sawabi for Tausug pis syabit weaving, Haja Amina Appi for the Sama mat weaving, and Eduardo Mutuc for Kapampangan silversmithing, all awarded in 2004; Magdalena Gamayo for Ilocano inabel weaving, and Teofilo Garcia for kattukong hat making, both in 2012.

Co-equal with the GAMABA as the highest state award is the National Artist Award. Pursuant to a decree signed by then president Ferdinand Marcos to recognize the contributions of Filipino artists, the title of National Artist was conferred on Fernando Amorsolo, 1972, because his “years of creative activity have defined and perpetuated a distinct element of the nation’s artistic and cultural heritage and won universal acclaim for our country and people;” Carlos V. Francisco, 1973, because “he transcended the narrow medium, investing his murals and easels with the robust spirit and infectious gaiety of the simple people whose joys and sorrows he captured on canvas with enviable fidelity;” Guillermo Tolentino, 1973, because “his restless search for the proper molds in which to pour his talents led him to commemorative sculptures which are delicate and classically balanced, and more often monumental with a scale and grandeur matched by no other sculptor of his time;” Napoleon Abueva, 1976, because “his massive abstractions and constructions of incredible variety and diversity, an unfailing inventiveness, a prodigious energy and inexhaustible inspiration firmly imprint his signature on the art of our time;” Victorio Edades, 1976, because he changed “the direction of Philippine painting decisively, ending the parochial isolation of Philippine art and placing it in the mainstream of international culture;” Vicente Manansala, 1981, because he left “a rich legacy of extraordinary achievements manifested in a large body of masterful works revealing the many facetedness of the outside world of fleeting time and of the mind;” Cesar Legaspi, 1990, because he refined “cubism in the Philippine context” and contributed “significantly to the advent and eventual acceptance of modern art in the Philippines;” and H.R. Ocampo, 1991, because “his courage and unique vision opened the way for a new language in painting that was freer, richer, and more poetic and for tirelessly seeking and refining an idiom that would be truly reflective of the Filipino society and sensibility.”

Subsequent awardees include Arturo Luz, 1997, who “created masterpieces that exemplify an ideal of sublime austerity in expression and form;” J. Elizalde Navarro, 1999, honored for his “40 years of drawing, printmaking, graphic designing, painting and sculpting” and his imaginative use of color; Ang Kiukok, 2001, whose expressionistic works were “imbued with nationalist fervor and sociological agenda:” Jose Joya, 2003, who “distinguished himself by creating an authentic Filipino abstract idiom that transcended foreign influences”; BenCab, 2006, whose works show that the “potency of figurative expression had held out vital options for Philippine art in the martial law years in the seventies through the contemporary era;” Abdulmari Imao, 2006, whose works popularized “the indigenous ukkil, sarimanok and naga motifs … and instilled in the consciousness of the Filipino nation;” Federico Aguilar Alcuaz, 2009, whose gestural paintings are characterized by “light, composition and color”; and Francisco Coching, 2014, whose “works reflected the dynamics brought about by the racial and class conflict in Philippine colonial society.”   Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz
Law, Censorship, and Ethics

As a mode of validation, law, censorship, and ethics influence the valuation of art in the public sphere. In the Philippines, the struggle between freedom of expression, institutional responsibilities, and state power would affect art practice and its circulation in society. An examination of the law would reveal two major tendencies that mark out the spectrum of legal attitudes toward art: protective on the one hand, and repressive on the other. The protective tendency of law with regard to art can be discerned in regulations that pertain to such areas as freedom of expression, cultural heritage, and intellectual property rights. The repressive tendency, usually exercised in the interest of a public that is presumed to be vulnerable to moral harm, is exemplified by regulations related to indecency, obscenity, and offenses against religious worship.

The law does not have to grapple directly with aesthetic questions or set down explicit definitions for art in order to affect the art world. For example, in a 1964 decision involving the artist Mauro Malang Santos, better known by the mononym “Malang,” the ruling of the Supreme Court on a matter of procedure wound up depriving the artist of the right to control how his work could be used, including the economic exploitation thereof. Malang had initiated an action for damages against the McCullough Printing Company for reproducing and selling a Christmas card design that he had made for the personal use of former ambassador Felino Neri. McCullough had retained Malang’s signature in the design, ensuring that he would be identified as the maker but had not obtained his consent for further circulating the reproduced image. Following the dismissal of his complaint by a lower court, the artist filed an appeal with the Supreme Court, alleging that said court had committed several errors in making its judgment. The lower court’s decision, however, was affirmed: it was established that Malang had failed to comply with the registration requirements of the copyright law in force at the time, and therefore the design had entered the public domain and was freely available for anyone to use.

Another instance might be the 2013 ruling of the Supreme Court on the dispute that had erupted around the 2009 roster of the Order of National Artists. Then president Gloria Macapagal Arroyo had decided to confer the honor upon seven individuals. Only three of them had been selected by the joint boards of the NCCA and the CCP: visual artist Federico Aguilar Alcuaz, filmmaker Manuel Conde, and writer Lazaro Francisco. The rest—comic book writer and film director Magno Jose Carlos J. Caparas, theater artist Cecile Guidote-Alvarez, architect Francisco Mañosa, and fashion designer Jose “Pitoy” Moreno—had been added by dint of presidential prerogative, which was also used to justify the removal of musicologist Ramon P. Santos, who had also been chosen by the NCCA and the CCP, together with Alcuaz, Conde, and Francisco. A number of concerned parties, which included National Artists Bienvenido Lumbera and Virgilio Almario, filed suit, alleging that Arroyo had committed grave abuse of discretion. The Supreme Court eventually ruled against the inclusion of Caparas, Guidote-Alvarez, Mañosa, and Moreno, but it believed that the omission of Santos was well within the president’s authority. However, Santos was eventually proclaimed National Artist for music in 2014.

In certain situations, the law or gatekeepers’ perception of what constitutes normative art has translated into preempted exhibition-making and thus the curtailment of freedom of creative expression. This has been demonstrated in cases wherein museum curators have intervened on behalf of their institutions and prevailed over the showing of work by artists who, in their judgment, could affront the sensibilities of persons in authority. This was exemplified in the 2003 pulling out of the work of artist Dindo Llana titled Naku! (Oh!), which satirizes President Arroyo, from the exhibit Letras y Figuras: Contemporary Idioms on Idea and Identity (Letters and Figures) at the Ayala Museum, which was keynoted by the Spanish ambassador and attended by President Arroyo. In 2007, to commemorate the centennial history of press freedom in the Philippines, the National Press Club commissioned the Neo-Angono Artists Collective to paint a mural, Sangandaan ng Kasaysayan ng Malayang Pamamahayag sa Pilipinas (Crossroads of History for Freedom of Expression in the Philippines). Ironically, the mural was subsequently altered by the commissioning party without the consent of the Neo-Angono Artists Collective, thereby changing the meaning and tone of the artwork.

Possibly the most prominent case thus far that spurred public focus on proposed limits to artist’s expressive leverage is the 2011 case laid against artist Mideo Cruz’s work, Poleteismo (Polytheism), shown in the Kulo (Boil) group exhibition of University of Santo Tomas Fine Arts alumni at the CCP Main Gallery.

The first public critique of Poleteismo circulated through the criminal investigation show XXX in ABS-CBN on 18 Jul 2011. The work was framed within the issue of the Reproductive Health Bill, focusing on the artist’s usage of condoms and phallic objects as elements in the installation. This was followed by numerous articles in mass media as well as innumerable posts and comments that went viral through the social media. After weeks of media coverage, the Cultural Center of the Philippines hosted a public forum titled “Dakdakan” on 5 Aug 2011 wherein contending parties confronted each other. The CCP Board of Trustees decided to close the exhibition on 8 Aug 2011 and announced this to the public the next day. This was followed by a senatorial inquiry on 16 Aug 2011, which ended with the decision to wait for the findings of the Office of the Ombudsman on the administrative and criminal cases filed. Among these was Manuel Dayrit’s administrative complaint against CCP Board of Trustees members Emily Abrera, Raul Sunico, Florangel Rosario-Braid, Jaime Laya, Isabel Caro Wilson, Zenaida Tantoco, Maria Cristina Turalba, Antonio Yap, Carolyn Espiritu, and CCP Visual Arts and Museum Division head Karen Ocampo Flores for violation of sections of Republic Act 6713 (Code of Conduct and Ethical Standard for Public Officials and Employees), while Eusebio Dulatas Jr charged Abrera and Sunico for grave misconduct and conduct unbecoming of a public officer or employee. Dayrit and Dulatas also filed separate criminal complaints for violation of paragraph 2(b), Article 201 (Immoral Doctrines, Obscene Publications and Exhibitions, and Indecent Shows) of the Revised Penal Code against Cruz and the previously mentioned CCP officials. Ombudsman Conchita Carpio Morales later dismissed the administrative and criminal cases in a 34-page joint resolution and a 30-page joint decision, both signed on 28 Feb 2013. The Office of the Ombudsman ruled that the showing of Poleteismo does not constitute an obscene act and that the censoring of the artwork effectively accomplished by calls for the early closure of the group exhibition constituted prior restraint as prohibited by the Philippine Constitution. The aborted showing precipitated by an arson attempt supposedly targeting the gallery prejudiced not only Cruz but also his fellow artists from publicly circulating their work under terms and within the duration agreed upon previously with the CCP.   Written by Jaime M. Salazar, with notes from Portia Placino and Maria Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez
