text:
Sections

Organizations and Collectives
Regional Art Organizations
Public Art Initiatives and Community-Based Projects
Related Content
Sources

 

The social and public aspect of art refers to the ways in which artists are organized through shared interests, be these regional, gender, ethnic, and ideological affiliations. In the history of art-making in the Philippines, artists have engaged the public on how to understand the meaning of art in society. Artists groups, organizations, and institutions initiate projects that address political, social, economic, cultural, and ecological concerns in the Philippines. These art initiatives inform us on the creative ways in which art performs a transformative role in society.

 

Organizations and Collectives

Organizations among visual artists have been formed to establish and maintain unity and harmonious working relationships between artists and to advocate for the welfare of artists and the development and upgrading of their art. In contemporary art practice, artists would also form collectives as a way to create collaborative work that explores issues in art expression, human rights, political freedom, environmental concerns, and community engagement.

The earliest-known organization devoted to artistic activities was the Sociedad de Artes y Oficios founded in Manila in May 1869. Intended to promote awareness in the arts and crafts, it also conducted workshops on drawing, engraving, carving, modeling, metal casting, and jewelry smithing. The trades taught included agriculture and dentistry. There were also classes on declamation and vocal and instrumental music.

In Nov 1877, the Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario was founded. It is particularly remembered because Jose Rizal won an award in one of its contests. The liceo (school) held its inaugural program on 23 Feb 1878 at the Teatro de Variedades, during which the painter Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo played the violin. On 29 Nov 1879, the liceo sponsored a literary, musical, and artistic competition in which Rizal won first prize for his poem “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth), and Juan Luna received a silver palette for Daphnis y Chloe (Daphne and Chloe). The provinces, following the trend in Manila, also founded artistic clubs. In Iloilo, for example, the Sociedad Artistico Literario de Iloilo was founded on 25 Oct 1893.

The Sociedad de Escultores de Santa Cruz, on the other hand, was the only organization comprised exclusively of sculptors. Founded in 1880, it had as members all the prestigious sculptors at the turn of the century. These included Ambrosio Garcia, Juan Toribio, Mariano Siauinco, Marcelo Nepomuceno, Aproniano Santos, Marcelo de la Rosa, Juan Flameño, Cayetano Castillo, Isabelo Tampinco, and Eulogio Garcia y Velarde. Founder and first president of the society was Romualdo Teodoro de Jesus.

The new American regime’s emphasis on education and the opportunities it opens led to the sprouting of clubs and organizations, many understandably devoted to art. The earliest art society founded in the American period was the Centro de Artistas established on 11 Feb 1904. This organization included painters, sculptors, musicians, and writers. While it sponsored literary-musical programs, it also served as a school. The Board of Directors was composed of painter-sculptor Eulogio Garcia Velarde, president; engraver Fernando Zamora, vice-president; painter Cecilio Gloria, treasurer; and sculptor Juan Flameño, vice-secretary. Since it offered courses on the various arts, heads were assigned for every department. Isabelo Tampinco served as head for architecture; Manuel Flores, sculpture; Ciriaco Gaudinez, silversmith; Toribio Antillon, painting; and Isidoro Roxas, music.

In 1908 the prestigious Asociacion Internacional de Artistas de Manila was founded. Perhaps the artists attached the term “internacional” to their group’s name because the founding members of this society, like Rafael Enriquez, Miguel Zaragoza, and Jose Maria Asuncion, were medalists of prestigious salon competitions abroad. There were also Spanish immigrants in the group like Armando Camps, Luis Viejo y Morena, and Augusto Fuster. The Asociacion Internacional was responsible for lobbying the inclusion of a college of fine arts as a unit in the University of the Philippines (UP) founded in 1908. The School of Fine Arts formally opened in 1909. Toward the end of the second semester of that year, the UP Fine Arts Society was founded. It was the most active artistic club in the country until the founding of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP).

Founded on 15 Feb 1948, the AAP, on the initiative of Purita Kalaw-Ledesma, an alumna of the UP School of Fine Arts, was originally conceived as an alumni association of the school. Its inaugural meeting was held at the Padre Faura building that now houses the Supreme Court. There were 13 charter members: Kalaw-Ledesma, Diosdado Lorenzo, Antonio Dumlao, Ramon Peralta Jr, Nemesio Faustino, Severino Fabie, Virginia Flor Agbayani, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Candido Alcantara, Dominador Castañeda, Francesco Monti, Alfredo Pestaño, and Fermin Sanchez. Kalaw-Ledesma was elected president and Peralta secretary; later, with growing membership, Agbayani was elected treasurer. Its first office was in a room at the National Museum made available by museum director Eduardo Quisumbing. The founding members decided upon an emblem in the form of an oval and a sprig of bamboo designed by Dumlao. Its constitution was patterned after the Artists’ Equity, an American organization, with the help of a visiting American artist Lily Harmon. Membership was open to painters, sculptors, graphic artists, art collectors, art patrons, and art lovers; they were classified as regular, honorary, patron, and associate. Its first public activity was a retrospective exhibit of the works of Fabian de la Rosa.

The AAP offered incentives to artists and sought to raise artistic standards. Its goals were accomplished primarily through annual art competitions. The members of the newly organized AAP paid a courtesy call on Pres Elpidio Quirino who consented to inaugurate the exhibition. The first AAP national art exhibition, held at the National Museum on 3 Jul 1948, gave the first prize to Carlos V. Francisco aka Botong Francisco. Other prizewinners were Lorenzo, Demetrio Diego, Vicente Manansala, Cesar Legaspi, and Hernando R. Ocampo aka H.R. Ocampo. The panel of judges consisted of Aguilar Cruz, Monti, Victorio Edades, and Fernando Amorsolo. From 1948 to 1950 the competitions were in painting; it was in the fourth annual exhibition in 1951 that sculpture entered the competition.

 

Due to increasing tension between the moderns and conservatives, two categories, the conservative and the modern, were instituted in 1949. However, the struggle between the two camps came to a head in the 1955 annual competition held at the Northern Motors Showroom. That year the competition coincided with the Rotary Golden Anniversary Awards, which offered a substantial prize and was the bone of contention between the two groups. In the Rotary Golden Anniversary Awards, the first prize was won by Galo B. Ocampo, the second prize by Manuel Rodriguez Jr aka Boy Rodriguez, and the third prize by Manansala. In the AAP annual competition, the first prize in the conservative category went to Arturo Luz, a modernist, while the winner in sculpture was Jose P. Alcantara. The conservative camp believed that the panel of judges was biased against them and staged the historic walkout from the AAP exhibit.

The founding of the AAP was followed by the opening of the Philippine Art Gallery (PAG). PAG was not only a gallery; it was also one of the first modern art institutions in the country. It became a full-fledged gallery on 30 May 1951, but its beginnings may be traced to the latter part of 1950, when a group of 11 women writers decided to organize a promotions and advertising outfit. This was first called Promotions Incorporated, and the women incorporators, headed by Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla, writer and widow of the short story writer Manuel Arguilla, were Flora Lansang, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, Consuelo Abaya, and Estrella Alfon. Romeo V. Tabuena was hired as staff artist to do the layout and design. The first office was on the third floor of the Palomo Building on O’Donnell corner Azcarraga (now Claro M. Recto St) in front of Aranque Market. Artist friends, like H.R. Ocampo, often paid visits.

The idea of a commercial art gallery began three months later when Arguilla began hanging paintings on the walls. These began to attract attention at a time when public art awareness had been enhanced by the founding of the AAP and the ongoing debates between the conservatives and the modernists. The wall on which the paintings were hung became known as the “Feature Wall” because it intended to present artists in a kind of one-person show. Tabuena was the first to be featured because he had enough paintings to show. Other artists who held one-person shows were Luz, Jose Joya, H.R. Ocampo, and Arguilla herself. Later, artists were invited to participate in group exhibits. Since it was a commercial gallery, it got a 30 percent commission from the sale of the works, prices of which ranged from 50 to 400 pesos.

After six months at the Palomo Building, the outfit moved to the second floor of the second house from the corner of Taft and Herran Streets between the Brown Derby and the Agoncillo Building where the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization held office. It was in this new location that Promotions Incorporated gave way to PAG, with Promotions functioning to promote PAG in the press. With the growing interest in Philippine art, it attracted not only artists but also writers, professors, poets, students, and other cultural personalities including cultural attachés of foreign embassies. PAG evolved into a busy art center with lecture forums, classes in art and music appreciation, flower arrangement and drawing from life, as well as lessons in Tagalog, Spanish, and French. To augment its income, the gallery printed Christmas cards designed by artists such as Manansala, Luz, Tabuena, Nena Saguil, Anita Magsaysay-Ho, and Cenon Rivera.

The first art collectors, such as Leandro V. Locsin, had PAG as their source. Among its commercial strategies was installment buying. It also held a monthly Premium Sale, which drew collectors and art lovers. The first was held on 2 Mar 1952. With a ticket priced at 5 or 10 pesos at most, one could win a painting by H.R. Ocampo, Legaspi, or Tabuena.

After a year, PAG transferred again due to a hike in rent which it could not meet. This time it moved to Room 201 of the nearby Petrona Apartments on 560 Taft Ave facing the Philippine General Hospital, at the invitation of Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil whose family owned the place. It was there that PAG celebrated its first anniversary with a big monthlong exhibition of paintings, photographs, and architectural designs, all of which occupied three floors of the building. After its second anniversary in the same location, PAG, through Arguilla’s efforts was able to put up a Philippine exhibit in the United States, where she stayed for a year. In her absence, PAG was managed by Cora Valencia and Arguilla’s half-brother, Peping Reyes.

On 22 Nov 1952, the Philippine Art Gallery Association was formed to firm up the finances of the gallery. Its officers were Saguil, H.R. Ocampo, Arguilla, and Mario Guerrero. Its members included Lorenzo, Manansala, Luz, Legaspi, Dumlao, Magsaysay-Ho, Joan Edades, Fernando Zobel, Victor Oteyza, Teddy Abueva, Nap Jamir, Ramon Estella, Max Lalata, Jose Joya, Amelia Lapeña, Virginia Moreno, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, Helen Roces Guerrero, Jose Maceda, Alberto Florentino, and a number of foreigners. An Apache Ball was held in 1953 to raise funds for the association.

PAG stayed at Petrona for more than a year. Due to financial constraints, it had to move to the Antonio Apartments at No. 4 Arquiza, off Mabini St in 1953. When Arguilla came back from the United States in Aug 1954, she recapitalized and renovated the gallery with the help of Joya and Victorio Edades who held a one-man show after its renovation. In 1954 a new set of officers were elected: Edades, president; H.R. Ocampo, vice-president; Arguilla, treasurer; and Oteyza and Jamir, directors.

In December 1955, Arguilla left again to join Operation Brotherhood in Laos where she met Pierre Salas, a film scriptwriter, whom she married. When she came back she paid all the back rentals, and a branch of the PAG was opened at 16 New York St, which was owned by her family. In 1957 there was another election of officers with Arguilla as president; Zobel, vice-president and secretary/treasurer; H.R. Ocampo, director-at-large; and Jesus Ayco, manager. In 1958 another branch was opened at No. 3 Williams St in Cubao jointly owned by Arguilla and her sister Remedios. It featured a studio-theater-gallery designed by Rodrigo Perez III. The Arquiza gallery was maintained but the New York branch was closed. At its inauguration, the gallery featured paintings of Rivera on the theme of the dance, while dances choreographed by Benny Villanueva, half-brother of Lydia, were performed by his students. Invited guests were the Bayanihan dancers under Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula and Lucrecia R. Kasilag.

Despite publicity campaigns, PAG on Williams St did not prosper and was closed down but the Arquiza branch was maintained up to the late 1960s. In 1968, Arguilla left for Geneva to join the Philippine Embassy as cultural attaché. It was there that she discovered she was ill with cancer. It was during this time that the Arquiza branch was closed and its belongings transferred to the house on Williams St, which many years later would be bought by Mario Alcantara who put up the Heritage Art Center. This burned down in 1989 and was relocated to Blue Ridge Subdivision in Quezon City. The existence of the PAG was coterminous with Arguilla, who died on 20 Dec 1969 (Kalaw-Ledesma 1987).

Other art organizations, most of them Manila-based, are Sining Bugkos, founded in the early 1980s, which is a regional alliance of cultural formations from urban communities, workers unions, and students from the National Capital Region (NCR); the Artista ng Bayan, founded in 1985 by Jose Tence-Ruiz, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Federico Sievert, Lito Mondejar, and Cap Reyes, among others, which aims to serve the community through art; Kabataang Tondo Art Group, founded by Fernando Sena, which conducts workshops for children in depressed areas such as Tondo; Christian Art Society of the Philippines; the Philippine Association of Printmakers, founded in 1962 by Manuel Rodriguez Jr; the Philippine Art Educators Association, established in 1968 by Araceli Dans and Brenda Fajardo, which aims to promote art education in the community by developing the students’ creativity and aesthetic sensitivity; Society of Philippine Sculptors, established in 1968 by Virginia Ty-Navarro and Napoleon Abueva, which sets a direction toward the upliftment of sculpture through interactions and initiation of new activities that address present concerns of the field; Samahang Kartunista ng Pilipinas, organized on 28 Feb 1978 by Lauro Alcala, Eduardo Aragon, Tito Milambiling, Renato Santiago, Edgardo Soller, Generoso Cabrera, Romeo Togonon, Hugo Yonzon Jr, and Paulino Galvez, which aims to work for the improvement of Filipino cartoonists and their profession. Other artists groups include the Saturday Group which meets every Saturday to sketch or paint together; the Dimasalang group, composed of landscape painters who are concerned with the effects of the Philippine sunlight, reviving a search initiated by Fernando Amorsolo; Artists’ Circle Fraternity and Sorority and Lingkod Sining, both from UP; and ANG, a group composed of graduates of the Philippine High School for the Arts.

 

With the heightened awareness of the crucial role of art in society, artist organizations and collectives were created to address various issues plaguing Philippine society. Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista at Arkitekto, a propaganda movement composed of “committed artists,” emerged in the 1970s; Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP), spearheaded by Lino Brocka, Behn Cervantes, Jose F. Lacaba, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, was founded in 1984 to help unite Filipino artists against the Marcos dictatorship. CAP is an organization of writers, artists, and cultural workers committed to the principles of freedom, justice, and democracy. Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan, founded in 1987, was composed of women artists advocating for awareness of gender issues in society. Salingpusa, active 1985-92, was founded by UP students whose primary goal is to make art more available to the public. Members of the Salingpusa, such as Elmer Borlongan, Manny Garibay, Tony Leaño, Ferdie Montemayor, Karen Flores, among others, would eventually form Sanggawa, active 1994-2000, an artist collective specializing in large-scale work and murals. UGATLahi Artist Collective, founded in 1992, used art as means of protest in street rallies, creating murals and effigies. Later in 2005, TutoK was formed with Flores, Iggy Rodriguez, and Mideo Cruz as core members, with the goal to commit art productions to the cause of human rights and freedom of expression. Youth- or student-based organizations are exemplified by Kabataang Artista para sa Tunay na Kalayaan, active ca 1990-2000, which had chapters in different universities, colleges, and communities in and out of NCR, with the goal of creating art for social change, genuine freedom, and national democracy.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Lisa Ito-Tapang

 

Regional Art Organizations

Many art associations have thrived in the regions. Artists from the north have drawn inspiration from the mountainous scenery and indigenous traditional cultures of the Cordilleras. Baguio and Sagada are home to many artists, at the same time that these places have attracted many from the lowlands to stay or at least to participate in communal art activities. The Baguio Arts Guild has drawn artists such as Santiago Bose and Roberto Villanueva. Bose has consistently worked in indigenous materials and used precolonial symbols. Villanueva is known for his open-air reed labyrinth archetype or Uma ti Biag (Kankanaey for “Garden of Life”) on the grounds of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1989. Aster Tecson, who used ethnic themes of political dimension, was also based in Sagada.

 

The painter/printmaker Benedicto Cabrera aka BenCab has also found Baguio congenial to his art. Some young artists associated with UP Baguio and led by Damay Demetillo at one time grouped under the name Taong Bundok and held a number of exhibits. Santiago Bose and Jordan Mang-osan devised a color-sculptural technique wherein wood is carved with the intense heat reflected from the sun’s rays by a magnifying glass. The trend in indigenous materials and themes spearheaded by Villanueva and Bose is strong among the northern artists. One of them, Cordillera-born Jordan Mang-osan, has developed an original form of solar painting. These are figure etchings in wood executed by the intense heat from the sun’s rays finely directed on the wooden surface by a magnifying glass. Aside from Baguio artists and residents, Manila artists working in indigenous materials have also participated in the Baguio art festivals.

The lakeshore town of Angono, Rizal, has produced a rich crop of artists. In the 1960s, the art of National Artist Carlos V. Francisco called attention to his native town of Angono where he chose to live and work. Best known for his historical murals, folk genre, and mythological paintings, he inspired generations of artists in his hometown, such as Jose Blanco, Perdigon Vocalan, Salvador Juban, and Nemesio Miranda Jr aka Nemiranda, who, together with Dominador Tiamson and other artists, founded in 1975 the Angono Ateliers Association. The artists later split into two groups: those who stayed with the Angono Ateliers and those who formed the Angono Artists Association. A number of young artists have founded the junior ateliers.

Taytay, a town adjacent to Angono, also has its share of artists. They have organized into the Group Artists of Taytay and had a big exhibit in Sep-Oct 1991 at the Galleria Manuela in Mandaluyong.

Tanay artists have also formed their own organization based in the studio of senior artist Martin Catolos who has a studio-workshop in Tanay; here young painters hone their skills in oil and watercolor under his tutelage and find a venue to exhibit their works.

Paete in Laguna is another art center in the Southern Tagalog region. In fact, its name is derived from paet, the chisel for wood carving, which was the principal town occupation even before the coming of the Spaniards. An old Paete master is Jose Dans, whose large painting depicting heaven, earth, and hell, graces a wall of the town church. The master wood-carver or santero is exemplified by Mariano Madriñan whose Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother) was exhibited in the Amsterdam International Exposition of 1883. So acclaimed were the Paete carvers that from 1876 to 1878 a number of them were employed to carve religious images for churches in Spain. Since the Spanish period, carving has been a communal activity structured around the family as guild, thus generations of families active to the present are the Madriñan, Caancan, Dans, Acupan, Adao, Caday, Palatino, Kadarnigara, Cagandahan, and Ac-ac. The contemporary carvers work in the manner of cooperatives such as in the groups called Likas Paete and Lilok Paete.

Lakan Sining ng Bulacan is a group that includes artists whose ancestral roots are in Bulacan, such as Joya, Al Perez, Roy Veneracion, and Florencio Concepcion. Aro Soriano also hails from Bulacan and does community workshops in painted terra-cotta figures.

In Pampanga, the towns of Angeles and San Fernando are sites of artistic activity. The commercial galleries in these towns were largely oriented to American patrons during the time when Clark Air Base was still in operation. In the 19th century, the portraitist Simon Flores y de la Rosa settled in Betis, Pampanga, where his paintings adorn the town church. During the American colonial period and the postwar years, a Pampango maestro was Vicente Alvarez Dizon who taught at the UP School of Fine Arts. A number of his descendants are active in the local art scene. The watercolorist Claude Tayag hails from Angeles, Pampanga. The Pampanga Arts Guild, based in Angeles City, was formed in the 1980s by a group of artists to conduct art workshops, exhibits, competitions, and exchange of ideas among artists in Central Luzon.

In the Visayas, Cebu has produced a large number of visual artists from the 19th century to the present. Cebu City and other towns, such as Carcar and Argao in the south, and Bogo and Bantayan in the north are known for their long artistic traditions. Old Cebuano masters include Canuto Avila of San Nicolas, Raymundo Francia of Parian, and Diosdado Desamparado Villadolid of Bantayan. An important Cebuano family of artists includes the patriarch Jose Trinidad Alcoseba of Carcar and his grandson Tony Alcoseba. A well-loved Cebuano maestro of portraits and landscapes was Martino Abellana, also an art teacher to an entire generation of artists. Another teacher-artist, as well as lepidopterist, is Julian Jumalon. In 1937, Jumalon, along with Oscar Figuracion, Ricardo Avila, Fidel Araneta, Silvestre Orfelia, Emilio Olmos, and Jose Trinidad Alcoseba formed the Cebu Arts Association, considered the oldest still-active organization for artists in the Philippines. The group promoted the visual arts in Cebu and became a venue for the exchange of ideas among artists. Other senior artists are Carmelo S. Tamayo of UP Cebu and Virgilio Daclan, who is active in art circles. Leading second-generation Cebuano artists are the Mendoza brothers (Sofronio aka SYM, Teofilo, and Godofredo), Romulo Galicano, and Gamaliel Subang.

Artists of Bacolod are among the most militant and the most organized. In 1983, when the late film director Brocka went to Bacolod during a human rights rally, the Pamilya Pintura and some other artists formed the CAP, Bacolod chapter, which spearheaded the mass movement in Bacolod. In 1986 two groups were formed: the Black Artists in Asia and the Dibuhista Gahiliugyon sa Negros.

One of the most dynamic Bacolod groups is the Black Artists in Asia (BAA), the adjective “black” referring to Negros island. Its core members, also the Pamilya Pintura core, were Norberto Roldan, Charlie Co, Nunelucio Alvarado, and Dennis Ascalon. BAA included cultural workers mostly in the visual arts and some in theater, such as Milton Dionson. For exhibit venue, it opened BAA gallery in Bacolod and BAA atelier under one roof. Aside from paintings, it has a strong craft orientation as it developed alternative art products, such as handmade paper, terra-cotta sculpture, postcards, glass etchings stone art, and printed T-shirts. Its objective was to produce works of social relevance linked to the issues in Negros. In 1986 the BAA was invited to Japan to hold an exhibition in an artist exchange program. This was followed by exhibits in Amsterdam and Sydney.

Efforts to organize Visayan artists include the Visayan Islands Visual Arts Exchange Conference or VIVA ExCon, a biannual affair supported by the CCP. In Feb 1990 it aimed to formulate Visayan aesthetics from the different islands. A leading Iloilo group is the Hubon Madia-as, with the Visual Arts Committee of the Arts Council as umbrella organization. Among its leading artists are Edward Defensor, visual and theater artist, and Nelson Ferraris. Gaudelia Doromal from UP Iloilo has also been active in the organization of the Arts Council, with the help of CCP, which holds the yearly Hublag Festival wherein artists from the Visayas and all over the country are invited to hold exhibits and performances in Iloilo City. Another Iloilo group is Pugaran, which stresses interaction with the community. Iloilo artists place importance on the use of indigenous materials and are highly innovative in their approach to art-making.

 

Davao City has also been a lively center of artistic activity in the visual arts and literature. Art Association Davao, a leading member of which was Ang Kiukok, featured the visual artists and creative writers active in this southern city; notable is the group’s Road Map series, each composed of a single sheet of paper folded like a map into pages of text or pictures. Victorio Edades, “Father of Modern Art in the Philippines,” settled in Davao City after the war and continued to paint there. Jose V. Ayala has done abstracts with a surrealist flavor and has had one-person shows in Manila. Working in different media, Ruben de Vera specializes in bird images and indigenous/ethnic subjects and has done powerful pen-and-ink drawings on social issues. George So does watercolors, acrylics, and pen-and-ink drawings, often realistic but at times in a surrealistic vein. Norberto Monterona from Iligan does portraits and genre paintings, using local textile paint applied to chipboards with bamboo sticks. Victor Secuya does drawings in an ink-blot style. Davao also has an outstanding crop of women painters, among them Tita Lacambra-Ayala and Lydia Rivera Ingle. The Talaandig artists, composed of the indigenous community in Bukidnon and led by Rodelio Linsahay Saway aka Waway, explored soil painting to depict the worldview of their people.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

Public Art Initiatives and Community-Based Projects

Contemporary art practices include a broad spectrum of engagements with communities of varied configurations. Artistic and creative strategies are effective means to shore affect, form communal bonds, and mobilize members of a community, whether long-standing or newly formed, rooted in a place or arising from an event. This development to great degree signals artists’ greater participation in social issues. As a consequence, it also speaks of their active production of a social discourse that interrogates art’s role in social life.

These practices are called a variety of names: collaborative, relational, participatory, or socially engaged art. While art projects and artistic practices differ, they share several attributes: a focus on collaboration, an emphasis on pedagogy, a loosely formed organization deemphasizing hierarchy, dialogue, and interconnectedness aided both by digital technology and a burgeoning network. While their projects transpire in community contexts, they also enter the exhibitionary circuit where often projects themselves are presented as images and texts through documentation and recordings. This array that best describes this emergent category of artistic practice also places in relief the changing status of artists in relation to the art they make as well as the shift in their associations with their audiences or viewers, or their co-creators.

Several platforms of engagement can be identified in the Philippine art scene. Most notable are artist groups or artist collectives (individual artists who gather and work on specific projects), art spaces, and of late, online venues or platforms. Many would be housed in physical spaces, several of which would provide a mix of uses. Others use spaces for specific projects and events and, moreover, rely on virtual space for interaction. Some would locate themselves on the ground or sites where their projects happen. The frequency of events also differs; some coincide with local festivals or are held in conjunction with international ones. While these artistic endeavors incorporate aspects of site-specificity, they manifest a marked turn toward interaction and “co-production,” further destabilizing notions of authorship and the roles of artists in art-making. This is exemplified by the following art spaces and projects: Shop 6 of Roberto Chabet from the 1970s to the 1980s, which supported mixed media constructions, installations, and site-specific works involving artists espousing guerrilla exhibits in homes, parks, and other venues; Pinaglabanan Galleries, founded by Agnes Arellano, which supported interactions between literary and visual arts from 1984 to 1990; Surrounded by Water, founded in 1998 by Wire Tuazon to serve as experimental platform for young artists; Big Sky Mind, co-founded by artists Ringo Bunoan and Katya Guerrero, which was initially a gallery-café and later became an independent artist-run space from 2001 to 2004; Green Papaya Art Projects, founded in 2000 by Norberto Roldan, Donna Miranda, Manny Chaves, and curator Bobi Valenzuela as a project space envisioning experimentation in art in a noncommercial venture; and Tupada Action and Media Art or TUPADA, founded 2002, composed of young artists interested in performance art in public spaces. Interest in art production involving local communities is exemplified by the Daambakal Sculptor’s Collective led by Rey Paz Contreras, which engages environmental issues in the urban context of Tondo.

Collaboration in art production does not only encompass work with members of communities but also entails partnerships with other organizations. These often large-scale projects happen over a length of time and are carried out with state agencies or with private support from foundations and funding bodies. A notable characteristic is the capacity to raise funds on their own; an example is 98B’s Weekend Market series. A lot of these initiatives would also have artists with thriving individual careers as members.

Artist initiatives organize events on singular runs or yearly intervals. The Neo-Angono Artists Collective, founded in 2004 in Rizal Province, organizes Neo-Angono Public Art Festival annually. A major element of the festival program is installation pieces and performance art. They can be found in the most unlikely places. A dried out stream bed for artist Wire Tuazon’s installation of a house on stilts with cement bags for walls, a replica of a boat stranded atop trees, a building and a belfry, or the altered signage of the local market are some examples. These works, like most others for the festival, all combine social commentary and feed off spontaneity and play, allowing for interesting encounters between art and viewers.

The Bagasbas Beach Eco Arts Festival in Daet, Camarines Norte, had three runs with installations and site-specific art installed along the beach as well as other sites. It had as participants local and international artists. This model is familiar, found in many points of the globe. However, one contention against so-called community art is the difficulty of making claims for how much art is able to accomplish in terms of enacting change. Much of the interactions that transpire are difficult to gauge, foremost because they are founded on intangible aspects of human interaction.

 

There are projects, however, that focus on direct engagement with communities devastated by tragedies and natural disasters. Artist Alma Quinto’s body of works has long delved into this practice. Her House of Comfort art project has traveled the archipelago as well as Japan. In the Philippines, Alma has worked with communities recovering from devastation of typhoons, floods, and armed conflict. She designs, organizes, and carries out workshops that enable participants to find their voice and recover their dreams. House of Comfort is a big house of dreams, patched from many hours of sewing and conversing. The house has been exhibited at various museums in different configurations.

The National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) also organized the Assistance for Crises Bureau with components Artist Teams for Crises and Creative Workshops. Workshops were conducted in the Visayas and Mindanao with plans of them being done all over the country. The program emphasized the role of the creative arts in the recovery of communities that suffered natural calamities and man-made disasters.

Artist groups (e.g., UGATLahi and TutoK) and spaces (e.g., Project Space Pilipinas and 98B) organize a series of activities on numerous themes focusing on activist projects, mobilizing community members for causes, wherein they become venues for pedagogy, sharing, and forging ties.

The AXIS Art Project has its roots in Baguio City and its vibrant art scene. Initiated by artist Kawayan de Guia in 2011, AXIS focuses on projects with collective memory and communities at their core. These include events at the 2011 Philippine Art Festival; an exhibition at the MO Gallery in Taguig, Metro Manila in 2012; the Haselma Axis Art Project, 2012; and its subsequent installation at the Singapore Biennale in 2013. They successfully brought together artists and audiences through various activities that utilized different platforms. Venues were diverse yet the creative encounters they fostered shared the qualities of the ephemeral, the itinerant, and mostly employing make-do strategies. AXIS project components are defined by travel and connection, interaction and conversation.

The 2011 Ipitik Festival was held alongside Baguio’s annual Panagbenga Festival. Activities for this Philippine Arts Festival included a pinikpikan cook-off (a traditional Cordillera dish distinct for having the live chicken beaten with a stick prior to cooking; the bruising brings blood to surface, rendering the meat more flavorful), a 108-gong performance by students, and the film events Cinema Rehiyon and the Asia-Africa Film Festival.

Most notable among the events at the 2011 Philippine Arts Festival were the making and installing of the AXIS Tent at the Rose Garden of Burnham Park and the Transient Studio, co-organized with artist Chris Yñiguez, at the Camp John Hay Library. Numerous activities took place inside the tent: wood carving, basket weaving, music, and crafts. People were free to pass through, visit and join the tent activities.

Transient Studio happened inside and around the perimeters of the run-down Camp John Hay Library. Participating artists made use of the ramshackle space, exhibiting works in what was an unlikely place for what we have come to know as contemporary art. Some utilized materials found on site, crafting installations and site-specific pieces that combined found material, words, performance, and live music.

The 2012 Haselma AXIS Art Project was inspired by the highway that Dangwa buses plied from Baguio City to the other points in Benguet province. For this, de Guia replicated the bus as a makeshift tent, propped and installed this at numerous stops during a five-day journey with artists traveling from Baguio. A distance of about 120 km was traversed, with artists engaging local communities through site-specific works. Aside from the tents, De Guia constructed a “snowman” from chicken dung on the highway’s highest peak, where tourists typically take photos. This was not only a commentary on the consumption of place but also an observation of the rapid degradation of the environment through harmful farming methods.

The Haselma AXIS Art Project also sought to collect objects along the Haselma Highway, reminiscent of artist Rene Aquitania’s Lakaran project of 1986. Aquitania hauled a vegetable cart from Manila to Baguio, picking and collecting objects along his path. These acts of itinerant collecting, however random and happening during different decades, are about piecing together collective memory and remembering place in a context frayed by conflict and challenged by hardships. AXIS firmly relocates not only the city of Baguio from de Guia’s memory but also counts upon art to redefine its relevance in contemporary life.

In 1995, the NCCA, through the National Committee on Visual Arts headed by Brenda V. Fajardo, came up with the Visual Art Congress and eventually gave birth to Sungdu-an, an exhibit platform participated in by visual artists from NCR, Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. Coined by the curator Roberto “Bobi” Valenzuela, sungdu-an is a Waray term for “confluence.” The 1st Sungdu-an: Pagtatagpo (Meeting) was held in 1996, using some of the rooms at the third floor of the NCCA Building. A room was assigned for each region, and it featured 100 works by artists representing Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. The second Sungdu-an was called Sambayan: Philippine Art and Culture Festival (One Nation: Philippine Art and Culture Festival), curated by Corazon Alvina and by regional curators when the exhibit traveled in various provinces in 2000. Forty works were featured, with each curator selecting 10 works that he/she felt represented his/her own interpretation of Sambayan’s general theme. The venues range from provincial museums and universities to plazas. The 3rd Sungdu-an: Making the Local, 2002-4, included a research component and six art projects initiated by curators who actually came from the regions: Estela Ocampo-Fernandez, Alfredo Aquilizan, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, and Abraham Garcia Jr. Rather than individual artists, artist groups and collaborations were prioritized, celebrating local art and empowering the local artists and organizations. The 4th Sungdu-an: ExTensions in 2007 was a scaled-down version of the second and third because of budget constraints. Held in Capitol University in Cagayan de Oro, it was organized by the members of the Printmaking Association of the Philippines. In 2009, Sungdu-an 5: Current: Daloy ng Dunong (Current: Flow of Knowledge) explored the current, the present, the “now”; and the transfer of knowledge and wisdom. Patrick D. Flores, the project director, focused on honing the curatorial skills of the artists aside from exploring themes beyond representation. Held at the National Museum of the Philippines, the curatorial roster included Dennis Ascalon for Visayas, Irma Lacorte for Luzon, Cris Rollo for Mindanao, and Claro Ramirez for NCR.   Written by Tessa Maria Guazon, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz and Lara Angelica Rosario

article.value: Sections

The social and public aspect of art refers to the ways in which artists are organized through shared interests, be these regional, gender, ethnic, and ideological affiliations. In the history of art-making in the Philippines, artists have engaged the public on how to understand the meaning of art in society. Artists groups, organizations, and institutions initiate projects that address political, social, economic, cultural, and ecological concerns in the Philippines. These art initiatives inform us on the creative ways in which art performs a transformative role in society.
Organizations and Collectives

Organizations among visual artists have been formed to establish and maintain unity and harmonious working relationships between artists and to advocate for the welfare of artists and the development and upgrading of their art. In contemporary art practice, artists would also form collectives as a way to create collaborative work that explores issues in art expression, human rights, political freedom, environmental concerns, and community engagement.

The earliest-known organization devoted to artistic activities was the Sociedad de Artes y Oficios founded in Manila in May 1869. Intended to promote awareness in the arts and crafts, it also conducted workshops on drawing, engraving, carving, modeling, metal casting, and jewelry smithing. The trades taught included agriculture and dentistry. There were also classes on declamation and vocal and instrumental music.

In Nov 1877, the Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario was founded. It is particularly remembered because Jose Rizal won an award in one of its contests. The liceo (school) held its inaugural program on 23 Feb 1878 at the Teatro de Variedades, during which the painter Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo played the violin. On 29 Nov 1879, the liceo sponsored a literary, musical, and artistic competition in which Rizal won first prize for his poem “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth), and Juan Luna received a silver palette for Daphnis y Chloe (Daphne and Chloe). The provinces, following the trend in Manila, also founded artistic clubs. In Iloilo, for example, the Sociedad Artistico Literario de Iloilo was founded on 25 Oct 1893.

The Sociedad de Escultores de Santa Cruz, on the other hand, was the only organization comprised exclusively of sculptors. Founded in 1880, it had as members all the prestigious sculptors at the turn of the century. These included Ambrosio Garcia, Juan Toribio, Mariano Siauinco, Marcelo Nepomuceno, Aproniano Santos, Marcelo de la Rosa, Juan Flameño, Cayetano Castillo, Isabelo Tampinco, and Eulogio Garcia y Velarde. Founder and first president of the society was Romualdo Teodoro de Jesus.

The new American regime’s emphasis on education and the opportunities it opens led to the sprouting of clubs and organizations, many understandably devoted to art. The earliest art society founded in the American period was the Centro de Artistas established on 11 Feb 1904. This organization included painters, sculptors, musicians, and writers. While it sponsored literary-musical programs, it also served as a school. The Board of Directors was composed of painter-sculptor Eulogio Garcia Velarde, president; engraver Fernando Zamora, vice-president; painter Cecilio Gloria, treasurer; and sculptor Juan Flameño, vice-secretary. Since it offered courses on the various arts, heads were assigned for every department. Isabelo Tampinco served as head for architecture; Manuel Flores, sculpture; Ciriaco Gaudinez, silversmith; Toribio Antillon, painting; and Isidoro Roxas, music.

In 1908 the prestigious Asociacion Internacional de Artistas de Manila was founded. Perhaps the artists attached the term “internacional” to their group’s name because the founding members of this society, like Rafael Enriquez, Miguel Zaragoza, and Jose Maria Asuncion, were medalists of prestigious salon competitions abroad. There were also Spanish immigrants in the group like Armando Camps, Luis Viejo y Morena, and Augusto Fuster. The Asociacion Internacional was responsible for lobbying the inclusion of a college of fine arts as a unit in the University of the Philippines (UP) founded in 1908. The School of Fine Arts formally opened in 1909. Toward the end of the second semester of that year, the UP Fine Arts Society was founded. It was the most active artistic club in the country until the founding of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP).

Founded on 15 Feb 1948, the AAP, on the initiative of Purita Kalaw-Ledesma, an alumna of the UP School of Fine Arts, was originally conceived as an alumni association of the school. Its inaugural meeting was held at the Padre Faura building that now houses the Supreme Court. There were 13 charter members: Kalaw-Ledesma, Diosdado Lorenzo, Antonio Dumlao, Ramon Peralta Jr, Nemesio Faustino, Severino Fabie, Virginia Flor Agbayani, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Candido Alcantara, Dominador Castañeda, Francesco Monti, Alfredo Pestaño, and Fermin Sanchez. Kalaw-Ledesma was elected president and Peralta secretary; later, with growing membership, Agbayani was elected treasurer. Its first office was in a room at the National Museum made available by museum director Eduardo Quisumbing. The founding members decided upon an emblem in the form of an oval and a sprig of bamboo designed by Dumlao. Its constitution was patterned after the Artists’ Equity, an American organization, with the help of a visiting American artist Lily Harmon. Membership was open to painters, sculptors, graphic artists, art collectors, art patrons, and art lovers; they were classified as regular, honorary, patron, and associate. Its first public activity was a retrospective exhibit of the works of Fabian de la Rosa.

The AAP offered incentives to artists and sought to raise artistic standards. Its goals were accomplished primarily through annual art competitions. The members of the newly organized AAP paid a courtesy call on Pres Elpidio Quirino who consented to inaugurate the exhibition. The first AAP national art exhibition, held at the National Museum on 3 Jul 1948, gave the first prize to Carlos V. Francisco aka Botong Francisco. Other prizewinners were Lorenzo, Demetrio Diego, Vicente Manansala, Cesar Legaspi, and Hernando R. Ocampo aka H.R. Ocampo. The panel of judges consisted of Aguilar Cruz, Monti, Victorio Edades, and Fernando Amorsolo. From 1948 to 1950 the competitions were in painting; it was in the fourth annual exhibition in 1951 that sculpture entered the competition.

article.value: Due to increasing tension between the moderns and conservatives, two categories, the conservative and the modern, were instituted in 1949. However, the struggle between the two camps came to a head in the 1955 annual competition held at the Northern Motors Showroom. That year the competition coincided with the Rotary Golden Anniversary Awards, which offered a substantial prize and was the bone of contention between the two groups. In the Rotary Golden Anniversary Awards, the first prize was won by Galo B. Ocampo, the second prize by Manuel Rodriguez Jr aka Boy Rodriguez, and the third prize by Manansala. In the AAP annual competition, the first prize in the conservative category went to Arturo Luz, a modernist, while the winner in sculpture was Jose P. Alcantara. The conservative camp believed that the panel of judges was biased against them and staged the historic walkout from the AAP exhibit.

The founding of the AAP was followed by the opening of the Philippine Art Gallery (PAG). PAG was not only a gallery; it was also one of the first modern art institutions in the country. It became a full-fledged gallery on 30 May 1951, but its beginnings may be traced to the latter part of 1950, when a group of 11 women writers decided to organize a promotions and advertising outfit. This was first called Promotions Incorporated, and the women incorporators, headed by Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla, writer and widow of the short story writer Manuel Arguilla, were Flora Lansang, Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido, Consuelo Abaya, and Estrella Alfon. Romeo V. Tabuena was hired as staff artist to do the layout and design. The first office was on the third floor of the Palomo Building on O’Donnell corner Azcarraga (now Claro M. Recto St) in front of Aranque Market. Artist friends, like H.R. Ocampo, often paid visits.

The idea of a commercial art gallery began three months later when Arguilla began hanging paintings on the walls. These began to attract attention at a time when public art awareness had been enhanced by the founding of the AAP and the ongoing debates between the conservatives and the modernists. The wall on which the paintings were hung became known as the “Feature Wall” because it intended to present artists in a kind of one-person show. Tabuena was the first to be featured because he had enough paintings to show. Other artists who held one-person shows were Luz, Jose Joya, H.R. Ocampo, and Arguilla herself. Later, artists were invited to participate in group exhibits. Since it was a commercial gallery, it got a 30 percent commission from the sale of the works, prices of which ranged from 50 to 400 pesos.

After six months at the Palomo Building, the outfit moved to the second floor of the second house from the corner of Taft and Herran Streets between the Brown Derby and the Agoncillo Building where the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization held office. It was in this new location that Promotions Incorporated gave way to PAG, with Promotions functioning to promote PAG in the press. With the growing interest in Philippine art, it attracted not only artists but also writers, professors, poets, students, and other cultural personalities including cultural attachés of foreign embassies. PAG evolved into a busy art center with lecture forums, classes in art and music appreciation, flower arrangement and drawing from life, as well as lessons in Tagalog, Spanish, and French. To augment its income, the gallery printed Christmas cards designed by artists such as Manansala, Luz, Tabuena, Nena Saguil, Anita Magsaysay-Ho, and Cenon Rivera.

The first art collectors, such as Leandro V. Locsin, had PAG as their source. Among its commercial strategies was installment buying. It also held a monthly Premium Sale, which drew collectors and art lovers. The first was held on 2 Mar 1952. With a ticket priced at 5 or 10 pesos at most, one could win a painting by H.R. Ocampo, Legaspi, or Tabuena.

After a year, PAG transferred again due to a hike in rent which it could not meet. This time it moved to Room 201 of the nearby Petrona Apartments on 560 Taft Ave facing the Philippine General Hospital, at the invitation of Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil whose family owned the place. It was there that PAG celebrated its first anniversary with a big monthlong exhibition of paintings, photographs, and architectural designs, all of which occupied three floors of the building. After its second anniversary in the same location, PAG, through Arguilla’s efforts was able to put up a Philippine exhibit in the United States, where she stayed for a year. In her absence, PAG was managed by Cora Valencia and Arguilla’s half-brother, Peping Reyes.

On 22 Nov 1952, the Philippine Art Gallery Association was formed to firm up the finances of the gallery. Its officers were Saguil, H.R. Ocampo, Arguilla, and Mario Guerrero. Its members included Lorenzo, Manansala, Luz, Legaspi, Dumlao, Magsaysay-Ho, Joan Edades, Fernando Zobel, Victor Oteyza, Teddy Abueva, Nap Jamir, Ramon Estella, Max Lalata, Jose Joya, Amelia Lapeña, Virginia Moreno, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, Helen Roces Guerrero, Jose Maceda, Alberto Florentino, and a number of foreigners. An Apache Ball was held in 1953 to raise funds for the association.

PAG stayed at Petrona for more than a year. Due to financial constraints, it had to move to the Antonio Apartments at No. 4 Arquiza, off Mabini St in 1953. When Arguilla came back from the United States in Aug 1954, she recapitalized and renovated the gallery with the help of Joya and Victorio Edades who held a one-man show after its renovation. In 1954 a new set of officers were elected: Edades, president; H.R. Ocampo, vice-president; Arguilla, treasurer; and Oteyza and Jamir, directors.

In December 1955, Arguilla left again to join Operation Brotherhood in Laos where she met Pierre Salas, a film scriptwriter, whom she married. When she came back she paid all the back rentals, and a branch of the PAG was opened at 16 New York St, which was owned by her family. In 1957 there was another election of officers with Arguilla as president; Zobel, vice-president and secretary/treasurer; H.R. Ocampo, director-at-large; and Jesus Ayco, manager. In 1958 another branch was opened at No. 3 Williams St in Cubao jointly owned by Arguilla and her sister Remedios. It featured a studio-theater-gallery designed by Rodrigo Perez III. The Arquiza gallery was maintained but the New York branch was closed. At its inauguration, the gallery featured paintings of Rivera on the theme of the dance, while dances choreographed by Benny Villanueva, half-brother of Lydia, were performed by his students. Invited guests were the Bayanihan dancers under Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula and Lucrecia R. Kasilag.

Despite publicity campaigns, PAG on Williams St did not prosper and was closed down but the Arquiza branch was maintained up to the late 1960s. In 1968, Arguilla left for Geneva to join the Philippine Embassy as cultural attaché. It was there that she discovered she was ill with cancer. It was during this time that the Arquiza branch was closed and its belongings transferred to the house on Williams St, which many years later would be bought by Mario Alcantara who put up the Heritage Art Center. This burned down in 1989 and was relocated to Blue Ridge Subdivision in Quezon City. The existence of the PAG was coterminous with Arguilla, who died on 20 Dec 1969 (Kalaw-Ledesma 1987).

Other art organizations, most of them Manila-based, are Sining Bugkos, founded in the early 1980s, which is a regional alliance of cultural formations from urban communities, workers unions, and students from the National Capital Region (NCR); the Artista ng Bayan, founded in 1985 by Jose Tence-Ruiz, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Federico Sievert, Lito Mondejar, and Cap Reyes, among others, which aims to serve the community through art; Kabataang Tondo Art Group, founded by Fernando Sena, which conducts workshops for children in depressed areas such as Tondo; Christian Art Society of the Philippines; the Philippine Association of Printmakers, founded in 1962 by Manuel Rodriguez Jr; the Philippine Art Educators Association, established in 1968 by Araceli Dans and Brenda Fajardo, which aims to promote art education in the community by developing the students’ creativity and aesthetic sensitivity; Society of Philippine Sculptors, established in 1968 by Virginia Ty-Navarro and Napoleon Abueva, which sets a direction toward the upliftment of sculpture through interactions and initiation of new activities that address present concerns of the field; Samahang Kartunista ng Pilipinas, organized on 28 Feb 1978 by Lauro Alcala, Eduardo Aragon, Tito Milambiling, Renato Santiago, Edgardo Soller, Generoso Cabrera, Romeo Togonon, Hugo Yonzon Jr, and Paulino Galvez, which aims to work for the improvement of Filipino cartoonists and their profession. Other artists groups include the Saturday Group which meets every Saturday to sketch or paint together; the Dimasalang group, composed of landscape painters who are concerned with the effects of the Philippine sunlight, reviving a search initiated by Fernando Amorsolo; Artists’ Circle Fraternity and Sorority and Lingkod Sining, both from UP; and ANG, a group composed of graduates of the Philippine High School for the Arts.

article.value: With the heightened awareness of the crucial role of art in society, artist organizations and collectives were created to address various issues plaguing Philippine society. Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista at Arkitekto, a propaganda movement composed of “committed artists,” emerged in the 1970s; Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP), spearheaded by Lino Brocka, Behn Cervantes, Jose F. Lacaba, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, was founded in 1984 to help unite Filipino artists against the Marcos dictatorship. CAP is an organization of writers, artists, and cultural workers committed to the principles of freedom, justice, and democracy. Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan, founded in 1987, was composed of women artists advocating for awareness of gender issues in society. Salingpusa, active 1985-92, was founded by UP students whose primary goal is to make art more available to the public. Members of the Salingpusa, such as Elmer Borlongan, Manny Garibay, Tony Leaño, Ferdie Montemayor, Karen Flores, among others, would eventually form Sanggawa, active 1994-2000, an artist collective specializing in large-scale work and murals. UGATLahi Artist Collective, founded in 1992, used art as means of protest in street rallies, creating murals and effigies. Later in 2005, TutoK was formed with Flores, Iggy Rodriguez, and Mideo Cruz as core members, with the goal to commit art productions to the cause of human rights and freedom of expression. Youth- or student-based organizations are exemplified by Kabataang Artista para sa Tunay na Kalayaan, active ca 1990-2000, which had chapters in different universities, colleges, and communities in and out of NCR, with the goal of creating art for social change, genuine freedom, and national democracy.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Lisa Ito-Tapang
Regional Art Organizations

Many art associations have thrived in the regions. Artists from the north have drawn inspiration from the mountainous scenery and indigenous traditional cultures of the Cordilleras. Baguio and Sagada are home to many artists, at the same time that these places have attracted many from the lowlands to stay or at least to participate in communal art activities. The Baguio Arts Guild has drawn artists such as Santiago Bose and Roberto Villanueva. Bose has consistently worked in indigenous materials and used precolonial symbols. Villanueva is known for his open-air reed labyrinth archetype or Uma ti Biag (Kankanaey for “Garden of Life”) on the grounds of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1989. Aster Tecson, who used ethnic themes of political dimension, was also based in Sagada.
