article.value: The painter/printmaker Benedicto Cabrera aka BenCab has also found Baguio congenial to his art. Some young artists associated with UP Baguio and led by Damay Demetillo at one time grouped under the name Taong Bundok and held a number of exhibits. Santiago Bose and Jordan Mang-osan devised a color-sculptural technique wherein wood is carved with the intense heat reflected from the sun’s rays by a magnifying glass. The trend in indigenous materials and themes spearheaded by Villanueva and Bose is strong among the northern artists. One of them, Cordillera-born Jordan Mang-osan, has developed an original form of solar painting. These are figure etchings in wood executed by the intense heat from the sun’s rays finely directed on the wooden surface by a magnifying glass. Aside from Baguio artists and residents, Manila artists working in indigenous materials have also participated in the Baguio art festivals.

The lakeshore town of Angono, Rizal, has produced a rich crop of artists. In the 1960s, the art of National Artist Carlos V. Francisco called attention to his native town of Angono where he chose to live and work. Best known for his historical murals, folk genre, and mythological paintings, he inspired generations of artists in his hometown, such as Jose Blanco, Perdigon Vocalan, Salvador Juban, and Nemesio Miranda Jr aka Nemiranda, who, together with Dominador Tiamson and other artists, founded in 1975 the Angono Ateliers Association. The artists later split into two groups: those who stayed with the Angono Ateliers and those who formed the Angono Artists Association. A number of young artists have founded the junior ateliers.
Taytay, a town adjacent to Angono, also has its share of artists. They have organized into the Group Artists of Taytay and had a big exhibit in Sep-Oct 1991 at the Galleria Manuela in Mandaluyong.

Tanay artists have also formed their own organization based in the studio of senior artist Martin Catolos who has a studio-workshop in Tanay; here young painters hone their skills in oil and watercolor under his tutelage and find a venue to exhibit their works.

Paete in Laguna is another art center in the Southern Tagalog region. In fact, its name is derived from paet, the chisel for wood carving, which was the principal town occupation even before the coming of the Spaniards. An old Paete master is Jose Dans, whose large painting depicting heaven, earth, and hell, graces a wall of the town church. The master wood-carver or santero is exemplified by Mariano Madriñan whose Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother) was exhibited in the Amsterdam International Exposition of 1883. So acclaimed were the Paete carvers that from 1876 to 1878 a number of them were employed to carve religious images for churches in Spain. Since the Spanish period, carving has been a communal activity structured around the family as guild, thus generations of families active to the present are the Madriñan, Caancan, Dans, Acupan, Adao, Caday, Palatino, Kadarnigara, Cagandahan, and Ac-ac. The contemporary carvers work in the manner of cooperatives such as in the groups called Likas Paete and Lilok Paete.

Lakan Sining ng Bulacan is a group that includes artists whose ancestral roots are in Bulacan, such as Joya, Al Perez, Roy Veneracion, and Florencio Concepcion. Aro Soriano also hails from Bulacan and does community workshops in painted terra-cotta figures.

In Pampanga, the towns of Angeles and San Fernando are sites of artistic activity. The commercial galleries in these towns were largely oriented to American patrons during the time when Clark Air Base was still in operation. In the 19th century, the portraitist Simon Flores y de la Rosa settled in Betis, Pampanga, where his paintings adorn the town church. During the American colonial period and the postwar years, a Pampango maestro was Vicente Alvarez Dizon who taught at the UP School of Fine Arts. A number of his descendants are active in the local art scene. The watercolorist Claude Tayag hails from Angeles, Pampanga. The Pampanga Arts Guild, based in Angeles City, was formed in the 1980s by a group of artists to conduct art workshops, exhibits, competitions, and exchange of ideas among artists in Central Luzon.

In the Visayas, Cebu has produced a large number of visual artists from the 19th century to the present. Cebu City and other towns, such as Carcar and Argao in the south, and Bogo and Bantayan in the north are known for their long artistic traditions. Old Cebuano masters include Canuto Avila of San Nicolas, Raymundo Francia of Parian, and Diosdado Desamparado Villadolid of Bantayan. An important Cebuano family of artists includes the patriarch Jose Trinidad Alcoseba of Carcar and his grandson Tony Alcoseba. A well-loved Cebuano maestro of portraits and landscapes was Martino Abellana, also an art teacher to an entire generation of artists. Another teacher-artist, as well as lepidopterist, is Julian Jumalon. In 1937, Jumalon, along with Oscar Figuracion, Ricardo Avila, Fidel Araneta, Silvestre Orfelia, Emilio Olmos, and Jose Trinidad Alcoseba formed the Cebu Arts Association, considered the oldest still-active organization for artists in the Philippines. The group promoted the visual arts in Cebu and became a venue for the exchange of ideas among artists. Other senior artists are Carmelo S. Tamayo of UP Cebu and Virgilio Daclan, who is active in art circles. Leading second-generation Cebuano artists are the Mendoza brothers (Sofronio aka SYM, Teofilo, and Godofredo), Romulo Galicano, and Gamaliel Subang.

Artists of Bacolod are among the most militant and the most organized. In 1983, when the late film director Brocka went to Bacolod during a human rights rally, the Pamilya Pintura and some other artists formed the CAP, Bacolod chapter, which spearheaded the mass movement in Bacolod. In 1986 two groups were formed: the Black Artists in Asia and the Dibuhista Gahiliugyon sa Negros.

One of the most dynamic Bacolod groups is the Black Artists in Asia (BAA), the adjective “black” referring to Negros island. Its core members, also the Pamilya Pintura core, were Norberto Roldan, Charlie Co, Nunelucio Alvarado, and Dennis Ascalon. BAA included cultural workers mostly in the visual arts and some in theater, such as Milton Dionson. For exhibit venue, it opened BAA gallery in Bacolod and BAA atelier under one roof. Aside from paintings, it has a strong craft orientation as it developed alternative art products, such as handmade paper, terra-cotta sculpture, postcards, glass etchings stone art, and printed T-shirts. Its objective was to produce works of social relevance linked to the issues in Negros. In 1986 the BAA was invited to Japan to hold an exhibition in an artist exchange program. This was followed by exhibits in Amsterdam and Sydney.

Efforts to organize Visayan artists include the Visayan Islands Visual Arts Exchange Conference or VIVA ExCon, a biannual affair supported by the CCP. In Feb 1990 it aimed to formulate Visayan aesthetics from the different islands. A leading Iloilo group is the Hubon Madia-as, with the Visual Arts Committee of the Arts Council as umbrella organization. Among its leading artists are Edward Defensor, visual and theater artist, and Nelson Ferraris. Gaudelia Doromal from UP Iloilo has also been active in the organization of the Arts Council, with the help of CCP, which holds the yearly Hublag Festival wherein artists from the Visayas and all over the country are invited to hold exhibits and performances in Iloilo City. Another Iloilo group is Pugaran, which stresses interaction with the community. Iloilo artists place importance on the use of indigenous materials and are highly innovative in their approach to art-making.

Davao City has also been a lively center of artistic activity in the visual arts and literature. Art Association Davao, a leading member of which was Ang Kiukok, featured the visual artists and creative writers active in this southern city; notable is the group’s Road Map series, each composed of a single sheet of paper folded like a map into pages of text or pictures. Victorio Edades, “Father of Modern Art in the Philippines,” settled in Davao City after the war and continued to paint there. Jose V. Ayala has done abstracts with a surrealist flavor and has had one-person shows in Manila. Working in different media, Ruben de Vera specializes in bird images and indigenous/ethnic subjects and has done powerful pen-and-ink drawings on social issues. George So does watercolors, acrylics, and pen-and-ink drawings, often realistic but at times in a surrealistic vein. Norberto Monterona from Iligan does portraits and genre paintings, using local textile paint applied to chipboards with bamboo sticks. Victor Secuya does drawings in an ink-blot style. Davao also has an outstanding crop of women painters, among them Tita Lacambra-Ayala and Lydia Rivera Ingle. The Talaandig artists, composed of the indigenous community in Bukidnon and led by Rodelio Linsahay Saway aka Waway, explored soil painting to depict the worldview of their people.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz
Public Art Initiatives and Community-Based Projects

Contemporary art practices include a broad spectrum of engagements with communities of varied configurations. Artistic and creative strategies are effective means to shore affect, form communal bonds, and mobilize members of a community, whether long-standing or newly formed, rooted in a place or arising from an event. This development to great degree signals artists’ greater participation in social issues. As a consequence, it also speaks of their active production of a social discourse that interrogates art’s role in social life.

These practices are called a variety of names: collaborative, relational, participatory, or socially engaged art. While art projects and artistic practices differ, they share several attributes: a focus on collaboration, an emphasis on pedagogy, a loosely formed organization deemphasizing hierarchy, dialogue, and interconnectedness aided both by digital technology and a burgeoning network. While their projects transpire in community contexts, they also enter the exhibitionary circuit where often projects themselves are presented as images and texts through documentation and recordings. This array that best describes this emergent category of artistic practice also places in relief the changing status of artists in relation to the art they make as well as the shift in their associations with their audiences or viewers, or their co-creators.

Several platforms of engagement can be identified in the Philippine art scene. Most notable are artist groups or artist collectives (individual artists who gather and work on specific projects), art spaces, and of late, online venues or platforms. Many would be housed in physical spaces, several of which would provide a mix of uses. Others use spaces for specific projects and events and, moreover, rely on virtual space for interaction. Some would locate themselves on the ground or sites where their projects happen. The frequency of events also differs; some coincide with local festivals or are held in conjunction with international ones. While these artistic endeavors incorporate aspects of site-specificity, they manifest a marked turn toward interaction and “co-production,” further destabilizing notions of authorship and the roles of artists in art-making. This is exemplified by the following art spaces and projects: Shop 6 of Roberto Chabet from the 1970s to the 1980s, which supported mixed media constructions, installations, and site-specific works involving artists espousing guerrilla exhibits in homes, parks, and other venues; Pinaglabanan Galleries, founded by Agnes Arellano, which supported interactions between literary and visual arts from 1984 to 1990; Surrounded by Water, founded in 1998 by Wire Tuazon to serve as experimental platform for young artists; Big Sky Mind, co-founded by artists Ringo Bunoan and Katya Guerrero, which was initially a gallery-café and later became an independent artist-run space from 2001 to 2004; Green Papaya Art Projects, founded in 2000 by Norberto Roldan, Donna Miranda, Manny Chaves, and curator Bobi Valenzuela as a project space envisioning experimentation in art in a noncommercial venture; and Tupada Action and Media Art or TUPADA, founded 2002, composed of young artists interested in performance art in public spaces. Interest in art production involving local communities is exemplified by the Daambakal Sculptor’s Collective led by Rey Paz Contreras, which engages environmental issues in the urban context of Tondo.

Collaboration in art production does not only encompass work with members of communities but also entails partnerships with other organizations. These often large-scale projects happen over a length of time and are carried out with state agencies or with private support from foundations and funding bodies. A notable characteristic is the capacity to raise funds on their own; an example is 98B’s Weekend Market series. A lot of these initiatives would also have artists with thriving individual careers as members.

Artist initiatives organize events on singular runs or yearly intervals. The Neo-Angono Artists Collective, founded in 2004 in Rizal Province, organizes Neo-Angono Public Art Festival annually. A major element of the festival program is installation pieces and performance art. They can be found in the most unlikely places. A dried out stream bed for artist Wire Tuazon’s installation of a house on stilts with cement bags for walls, a replica of a boat stranded atop trees, a building and a belfry, or the altered signage of the local market are some examples. These works, like most others for the festival, all combine social commentary and feed off spontaneity and play, allowing for interesting encounters between art and viewers.

The Bagasbas Beach Eco Arts Festival in Daet, Camarines Norte, had three runs with installations and site-specific art installed along the beach as well as other sites. It had as participants local and international artists. This model is familiar, found in many points of the globe. However, one contention against so-called community art is the difficulty of making claims for how much art is able to accomplish in terms of enacting change. Much of the interactions that transpire are difficult to gauge, foremost because they are founded on intangible aspects of human interaction.

There are projects, however, that focus on direct engagement with communities devastated by tragedies and natural disasters. Artist Alma Quinto’s body of works has long delved into this practice. Her House of Comfort art project has traveled the archipelago as well as Japan. In the Philippines, Alma has worked with communities recovering from devastation of typhoons, floods, and armed conflict. She designs, organizes, and carries out workshops that enable participants to find their voice and recover their dreams. House of Comfort is a big house of dreams, patched from many hours of sewing and conversing. The house has been exhibited at various museums in different configurations.

The National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) also organized the Assistance for Crises Bureau with components Artist Teams for Crises and Creative Workshops. Workshops were conducted in the Visayas and Mindanao with plans of them being done all over the country. The program emphasized the role of the creative arts in the recovery of communities that suffered natural calamities and man-made disasters.

Artist groups (e.g., UGATLahi and TutoK) and spaces (e.g., Project Space Pilipinas and 98B) organize a series of activities on numerous themes focusing on activist projects, mobilizing community members for causes, wherein they become venues for pedagogy, sharing, and forging ties.

The AXIS Art Project has its roots in Baguio City and its vibrant art scene. Initiated by artist Kawayan de Guia in 2011, AXIS focuses on projects with collective memory and communities at their core. These include events at the 2011 Philippine Art Festival; an exhibition at the MO Gallery in Taguig, Metro Manila in 2012; the Haselma Axis Art Project, 2012; and its subsequent installation at the Singapore Biennale in 2013. They successfully brought together artists and audiences through various activities that utilized different platforms. Venues were diverse yet the creative encounters they fostered shared the qualities of the ephemeral, the itinerant, and mostly employing make-do strategies. AXIS project components are defined by travel and connection, interaction and conversation.

The 2011 Ipitik Festival was held alongside Baguio’s annual Panagbenga Festival. Activities for this Philippine Arts Festival included a pinikpikan cook-off (a traditional Cordillera dish distinct for having the live chicken beaten with a stick prior to cooking; the bruising brings blood to surface, rendering the meat more flavorful), a 108-gong performance by students, and the film events Cinema Rehiyon and the Asia-Africa Film Festival.

Most notable among the events at the 2011 Philippine Arts Festival were the making and installing of the AXIS Tent at the Rose Garden of Burnham Park and the Transient Studio, co-organized with artist Chris Yñiguez, at the Camp John Hay Library. Numerous activities took place inside the tent: wood carving, basket weaving, music, and crafts. People were free to pass through, visit and join the tent activities.

Transient Studio happened inside and around the perimeters of the run-down Camp John Hay Library. Participating artists made use of the ramshackle space, exhibiting works in what was an unlikely place for what we have come to know as contemporary art. Some utilized materials found on site, crafting installations and site-specific pieces that combined found material, words, performance, and live music.

The 2012 Haselma AXIS Art Project was inspired by the highway that Dangwa buses plied from Baguio City to the other points in Benguet province. For this, de Guia replicated the bus as a makeshift tent, propped and installed this at numerous stops during a five-day journey with artists traveling from Baguio. A distance of about 120 km was traversed, with artists engaging local communities through site-specific works. Aside from the tents, De Guia constructed a “snowman” from chicken dung on the highway’s highest peak, where tourists typically take photos. This was not only a commentary on the consumption of place but also an observation of the rapid degradation of the environment through harmful farming methods.

The Haselma AXIS Art Project also sought to collect objects along the Haselma Highway, reminiscent of artist Rene Aquitania’s Lakaran project of 1986. Aquitania hauled a vegetable cart from Manila to Baguio, picking and collecting objects along his path. These acts of itinerant collecting, however random and happening during different decades, are about piecing together collective memory and remembering place in a context frayed by conflict and challenged by hardships. AXIS firmly relocates not only the city of Baguio from de Guia’s memory but also counts upon art to redefine its relevance in contemporary life.

In 1995, the NCCA, through the National Committee on Visual Arts headed by Brenda V. Fajardo, came up with the Visual Art Congress and eventually gave birth to Sungdu-an, an exhibit platform participated in by visual artists from NCR, Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. Coined by the curator Roberto “Bobi” Valenzuela, sungdu-an is a Waray term for “confluence.” The 1st Sungdu-an: Pagtatagpo (Meeting) was held in 1996, using some of the rooms at the third floor of the NCCA Building. A room was assigned for each region, and it featured 100 works by artists representing Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. The second Sungdu-an was called Sambayan: Philippine Art and Culture Festival (One Nation: Philippine Art and Culture Festival), curated by Corazon Alvina and by regional curators when the exhibit traveled in various provinces in 2000. Forty works were featured, with each curator selecting 10 works that he/she felt represented his/her own interpretation of Sambayan’s general theme. The venues range from provincial museums and universities to plazas. The 3rd Sungdu-an: Making the Local, 2002-4, included a research component and six art projects initiated by curators who actually came from the regions: Estela Ocampo-Fernandez, Alfredo Aquilizan, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, and Abraham Garcia Jr. Rather than individual artists, artist groups and collaborations were prioritized, celebrating local art and empowering the local artists and organizations. The 4th Sungdu-an: ExTensions in 2007 was a scaled-down version of the second and third because of budget constraints. Held in Capitol University in Cagayan de Oro, it was organized by the members of the Printmaking Association of the Philippines. In 2009, Sungdu-an 5: Current: Daloy ng Dunong (Current: Flow of Knowledge) explored the current, the present, the “now”; and the transfer of knowledge and wisdom. Patrick D. Flores, the project director, focused on honing the curatorial skills of the artists aside from exploring themes beyond representation. Held at the National Museum of the Philippines, the curatorial roster included Dennis Ascalon for Visayas, Irma Lacorte for Luzon, Cris Rollo for Mindanao, and Claro Ramirez for NCR.   Written by Tessa Maria Guazon, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz and Lara Angelica Rosario
